  • § 33-25-112.  Hearing and appeal procedures.
  • § 33-25-113.  Fees.
  • § 33-25-114.  Penalties.
  • § 33-25-115.  Actions against board members; defense.
  • § 33-25-116.  Injunctive relief; grounds.

Cross references. —

As to licensing provisions generally, see chapter 1 of this title.

As to chiropractors, see chapter 10 of this title.

As to nurses, see chapter 21 of this title.

For the Wyoming Pharmacy Act, see chapter 24 of this title.

As to physicians and surgeons, see chapter 26 of this title.

As to eye care practitioners, see chapter 32 of this title.

Stated in

Paravecchio v. Memorial Hosp., 742 P.2d 1276, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 507 (Wyo. 1987).

§ 33-25-101. Definitions.

  1. As used in this act:
    1. “Physical therapy” or “physiotherapy” means the care and services provided by or under the direction and supervision of a physical therapist or physiotherapist who is licensed pursuant to this act. The practice of physical therapy includes:
      1. Examining, evaluating and testing persons with mechanical, physiological or developmental impairments, functional limitations, disabilities or other health or movement related conditions to determine a physical therapy diagnosis, prognosis or plan of treatment and assessing the ongoing effects of intervention;
      2. Alleviating impairments, functional limitations or disabilities by designing, implementing or modifying treatment interventions that may include but are not limited to:
        1. Therapeutic exercise;
        2. Functional activities in the home;
        3. Community or work integration or reintegration;
        4. Manual therapy, which includes mobilization and grades I through IV manipulation of joints and soft tissue but does not include grade V manipulations without completion of advanced training requirements as determined by the board;
        5. Therapeutic massage;
        6. Prescription, application or fabrication of appropriate assistive, adaptive, protective or supportive devices or equipment;
        7. Airway clearance techniques;
        8. Integumentary protection or repair techniques;
        9. Wound care;
        10. Application of physical agents or modalities;
        11. Mechanical modalities;
        12. Patient related instruction.
      3. Reducing the risk of injury, impairment, functional limitation or disability, including the promotion and maintenance of fitness, health and wellness.
    2. “Physical therapist” or “physiotherapist” means a person who is licensed to practice physical therapy pursuant to this act;
    3. “Board” means the Wyoming board of physical therapy as established under the provisions of this act;
    4. “Applicant” means any individual who submits a completed application to the board for issuance of a physical therapist license or a physical therapist assistant certificate;
    5. “Physical therapist assistant” means an individual who is certified pursuant to this act and who assists a licensed physical therapist in lawfully delegated components of physical therapy subject to the provisions of this act and rules and regulations of the board;
    6. “Physical therapy services” means the care and services provided by a licensed physical therapist or a certified physical therapist assistant pursuant to this act;
    7. “Consultation using telecommunication” means the provision of professional or expert opinion or advice to a physical therapist or other health care provider using telecommunication or computer technology from a distant location. It includes the review or transfer of patient records or related information using audio, video or data communications;
    8. “Jurisdiction” means the states, districts, territories or possessions of the United States;
    9. “On site supervision” means the supervising physical therapist or physical therapist assistant is continuously present in the facility where the supervised services are provided, is immediately available to the person being supervised and maintains continued involvement in each treatment session;
    10. “Physical therapy aide” means a person trained under the direction of a licensed physical therapist who performs designated and supervised components of care related to physical therapy;
    11. “Physical therapy diagnosis” means a systematic examination process that culminates in assigning a diagnostic label identifying the primary dysfunction towards which physical therapy treatment will be directed, but shall not include a medical diagnosis or a diagnosis of disease;
    12. “This act” means W.S. 33-25-101 through 33-25-116 .

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.1; Laws 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 2009, ch. 134, § 2.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a)(i), inserted “or ‘physiotherapy’ ” following “ ‘Physical therapy’ ” and substituted “the care and services provided by or under the direction and supervision of a physical therapist or physiotherapist who is licensed pursuant to this act. The practice of physical therapy includes” for the evaluation, instruction or treatment of a human being to prevent, correct, alleviate or limit physical disability due to injury, disease or any other physical or mental condition by the utilization of physical measures such as exercise, massage, heat, cold, air, light, water, electricity or sound, and rehabilitative procedures including training in functional activities and the performance and interpretation of tests and measurements of bodily functions as an aid in the examination, evaluation or treatment of any human conditions for the purpose of correcting or alleviating an individual's physical or mental disability. Physical therapy also includes the supervision of physical therapy activities, physical therapy consultation and the establishment and modification of physical therapy programs, but physical therapy shall not include radiology or electro-surgery or authorize the diagnosis of disease. Treatment by physical therapy shall be rendered subject to W.S. 33-25-102 ”; added (a)(i)(A) through (a)(i)(C); in (a)(ii), added “or ‘physiotherapist’ ” following “ ‘Physical therapist’ ”; rewrote (a)(iv), which read: “ ‘Applicant’ means any individual who has applied to the board for licensure as a physical therapist or registration as a physical therapist assistant and whose application is pending, awaiting decision by the board”; in (a)(v), inserted “is certified pursuant to this act and who” following “an individual who”, inserted “in lawfully delegated components of physical therapy” following “licensed physical therapist”, and substituted “rules and regulations of the board” for “rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, and who has met all the requirements of this act”; in (a)(vi), inserted “the care and” preceding “services”, inserted “licensed” preceding “physical therapist”, inserted “certified” preceding “physical therapist assistant”, and deleted “licensed” preceding “pursuant to this act”; added (a)(vii) through (a)(xi) and redesignated the remaining paragraph accordingly; and in (a)(xii), substituted “33-25-116” for “33-25-115.”

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 33-25-102. Practice of physical therapy; license or certificate required; exceptions; false representations.

  1. No individual shall engage in the practice of physical therapy services nor hold himself out as being able to practice physical therapy in the state of Wyoming unless he is licensed or certified in accordance with the provisions of this act and such license or certificate is in good standing and has not been suspended or revoked, except nothing in this act shall:
    1. Prohibit any individual licensed in Wyoming under any other act from engaging in the practice for which he is licensed;
    2. Prohibit students who are enrolled in educational courses of physical therapy at schools recognized by the board from performing acts of physical therapy incidental to their respective courses of study while under the direct supervision of a licensed physical therapist who is in compliance with subsection (c) of this section;
    3. Apply to any individual employed by an agency, bureau or division of the federal government while in the discharge of official duties;
    4. Repealed by Laws 2009, ch. 165, § 2.
  2. No individual or business entity shall use in connection with his name or business, the words physical therapy, physical therapist, physiotherapy, physiotherapist, registered physical therapist, licensed physical therapist, doctor of physical therapy or the letters P.T., L.P.T., R.P.T., D.P.T., M.P.T., M.S.P.T. or any other words, letters, abbreviations or insignia indicating or implying directly or indirectly that physical therapy is provided or supplied in any manner unless the person is a physical therapist licensed to practice in accordance with this act. No individual or business entity shall use the title physical therapist assistant, the letters P.T.A. or any other words, abbreviations or insignia in connection with his name to indicate or imply that the person is a physical therapist assistant unless the person is certified as a physical therapist assistant in accordance with this act.
  3. A physical therapist may initiate physical therapy with or without a prescription from a licensed physician or other health care provider, except that a physical therapist shall refer a patient or client to another health care provider to diagnose or care for the patient or client if the physical therapist reasonably believes that symptoms or conditions may be present that require health care services beyond the scope of physical therapy practice, or physical therapy is contraindicated.
    1. through (iii) Repealed by Laws 2019, ch. 12, §  2.
  4. Physical therapy aides may perform patient care activities as defined by the board under the on-site supervision of a licensed physical therapist or a certified physical therapist assistant.
  5. Prior to any physical therapy service, the patient or client shall be directed to posted information and delivered a handout explaining:
    1. The education level and degrees held by the treating physical therapist;
    2. That coverage may not be available through governmental or worker’s compensation programs unless prescribed by a physician, physician’s assistant, dentist, chiropractor, podiatrist or nurse practitioner; and
    3. That the patient’s or client’s insurance may not cover the service.
  6. The following persons are exempt from the licensure and certification requirements of this act:
    1. A person in a professional education program approved by the board who is satisfying supervised clinical education requirements related to the person’s physical therapist education while under on-site supervision of a licensed physical therapist;
    2. A physical therapist who is practicing exclusively through the United States armed services, public health service or veterans administration;
    3. A physical therapist licensed to practice physical therapy in another jurisdiction while teaching, demonstrating, providing physical therapy in connection with teaching or participating in an educational seminar in Wyoming. An exemption under this paragraph shall not exceed sixty (60) days cumulatively in a calendar year;
    4. A physical therapist licensed in another jurisdiction who provides consultation using telecommunication;
    5. A physical therapist licensed in another jurisdiction or credentialed in another country who provides therapy to individuals affiliated with or employed by established athletic teams, athletic organizations or performing arts companies temporarily practicing, competing or performing in the state. An exemption under this paragraph shall not exceed sixty (60) days cumulatively in a calendar year;
    6. A physical therapist licensed in another jurisdiction who enters this state to provide physical therapy during a public health emergency as declared by the governor pursuant to W.S. 35-4-115(a)(i). Any physical therapist practicing pursuant to this paragraph shall notify the board of the therapist’s intent to practice and supply additional information as provided by rules of the board;
    7. A physical therapist licensed in another jurisdiction who is forced to leave his residence or place of employment due to a declared local, state or national disaster or emergency and who seeks to practice physical therapy in Wyoming. An exemption under this paragraph shall be limited to sixty (60) days following the declaration of disaster or emergency. Any physical therapist practicing pursuant to this paragraph shall notify the board of the therapist’s intent to practice and supply additional information as provided by rules of the board.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 2; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.2; Laws 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 1997, ch. 117, § 1; 1999, ch. 195, § 1; 2003, ch. 29, § 1; ch. 111, § 1; 2009, ch. 134, § 2; ch. 165, § 2; 2019, ch. 12, §§ 1, 2.

The 2009 amendments. —

The first 2009 amendment, by Laws 2009, ch. 134, § 2, effective July 1, 2009, in (a), deleted “From and after January 1, 1962” from the beginning, substituted “engage in the practice of physical therapy” for “provide physical therapy”, inserted “or certified” following “licensed”, and inserted “or certificate” following “license”; in (b), in the first sentence, substituted “No individual or business entity” for “No person”, inserted “licensed physical therapist, doctor of physical therapy” following “registered physical therapist”, inserted “D.P.T., M.P.T., M.S.P.T” following “R.P.T.”, substituted “unless the person is a physical therapist” for “when the person is not a physical therapist or physical therapist assistant”, and added the second sentence; in (c), in the third sentence, substituted “Except in an emergency, a physical therapist, without a prescription” for “Without a prescription, a physical therapist”; in (d), substituted “Physical therapy aides” for “Assistive personnel” and substituted “certified physical therapist assistant” for “registered physical therapist assistant”; in (e)(ii), inserted “dentist, chiropractor, podiatrist” preceding “or nurse practitioner”; and added (f).

The second 2009 amendment, by Laws 2009, ch. 165, § 2, effective July 1, 2009, repealed (a)(iv), which read: “Prohibit an athletic trainer certified by a national athletic trainers' certification organization approved by the board from providing athletic training services to participating athletes of an educational institution or a professional or bona fide amateur sports organization at the institution or organization's athletic training facility or at the site of athletic practice or competition, provided that no person shall use in connection with his name or activity the words ‘athletic trainer’ or ‘athletic training’ or the letters ‘AT’ or ‘ATC’ unless the person is certified as provided by this paragraph.”

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2019 amendments. — The first 2019 amendment, by ch. 12, § 1, effective July 1, 2019, in (c) substituted “A” for “Except as provided in this subsection,” deleted “with a master's degree, or a bachelor's degree with five (5) years of clinical experience” and “treatment for a new or recurring injury” and substituted “or other health care provider, except that a physical therapist shall refer a patient or client to another health care provider to diagnose or care for the patient or client if the physical therapist reasonably believes that symptoms or conditions may be present that require health care services beyond the scope of physical therapy practice, or physical therapy is contraindicated” for “including doctor of osteopathy, podiatrist, advanced practitioner of nursing, dentist, chiropractor or physician assistant. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to preclude a physical therapist from treating a chronic or recurring injury or condition without a prescription, provided that the patient or client was previously diagnosed and prescribed physical therapy treatment within the previous year by a health care provider identified in this subsection and the treatment is directly related to the original prescribed care. Except in an emergency, a physical therapist, without a prescription, is prohibited from initiating physical therapy treatment for children under the age of twelve (12) years, unless the child is to receive physical therapy treatment under an individualized education program or an individualized family services plan. A physical therapist shall refer the patient or client to a licensed physician including doctor of osteopathy, podiatrist, advanced practitioner of nursing, dentist, chiropractor or physician assistant, as appropriate, when.”

Laws 2019, ch. 12, § 3, makes the act effective July 1, 2019.

The second 2019 amendment, by ch. 12, § 2, effective July 1, 2019, repealed former (c)(i) through (c)(iii) which read: “(i) The physical therapist has reasonable cause to believe symptoms or conditions are present that require services beyond the scope of physical therapy practice; (ii) Physical therapy is contradicated; or (iii) Except for patients or clients participating in general exercise or fitness programs or receiving physical therapy services under an individualized education program or an individualized family services plan, the patient or client has received physical therapy services without a prescription for twelve (12) visits or for a thirty (30) day period, whichever occurs earlier, and further services may be necessary.”

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

Laws 2019, ch. 12, § 3, makes the act effective July 1, 2019.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-25-101(a)(xii).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Licensing and regulation of practice of physical therapy, 8 ALR5th 825.

§ 33-25-103. Board of physical therapy; established; members; terms; removal; compensation.

  1. There is established the Wyoming board of physical therapy which shall consist of three (3) physical therapists licensed pursuant to this act, one (1) public representative and one (1) medical doctor, appointed as follows:
    1. The physical therapist members shall be appointed by the governor. All shall be residents of Wyoming, possess unrestricted licenses to practice physical therapy in this state and have been practicing in this state for not less than three (3) years before appointment;
    2. A medical doctor shall be appointed to the board by the governor. The medical doctor shall be a practicing physician who has practiced in Wyoming for a period of at least five (5) years immediately preceding the appointment;
    3. The public member shall be appointed by the governor, shall be a resident of Wyoming and shall have resided in the state for not less than three (3) years.
  2. Terms of office for board members shall be for four (4) years, except that the expiring term of a member shall continue until a successor member has been appointed. Board members shall serve no more than two (2) consecutive terms. The governor may remove any member as provided in W.S. 9-1-202 .
  3. Members of the board shall each receive from the physical therapy account compensation at the salary rate provided in W.S. 28-5-101(d) for each day actually spent in the performance of their board duties along with per diem and mileage as provided in W.S. 33-1-302(a)(vii). Board members shall serve without compensation where there are insufficient monies in the account to pay the compensation.
  4. Vacancies on the board shall be filled in a like manner as are the original appointments, to complete the unexpired term left vacant.
  5. The members shall annually select a president and secretary who shall each serve a one (1) year term of office from the date of election.
  6. The board shall meet at least twice annually and at such other times as the board deems necessary. Action by the board shall be by majority vote. Three (3) members constitute a quorum.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 3; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.3; Laws 1971, ch. 172, §§ 1, 2; 1973, ch. 179, § 1; ch. 245, § 3; 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 1987, ch. 175, § 1; 2009, ch. 134, § 2; 2014, ch. 69, § 2.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a)(i), deleted “from a list of five (5) qualified physical therapists submitted by the Wyoming chapter of American Physical Therapy Association” from the end of the first sentence, substituted “possess unrestricted licenses to practice physical therapy in this state and have been practicing in this state for not less than three (3) years before appointment” for “and practitioners of physical therapy” in the second sentence, and deleted the third sentence, which read: “They shall meet all requirements established by the American Physical Therapy Association for registry of members and shall have practiced a minimum of three (3) years in Wyoming”; in (a)(ii), deleted “from a list of five (5) medical doctors, recommended on the basis of interest in physical therapy, by the Wyoming chapter of the American Physical Therapy Association” from the end of the first sentence, and substituted “The medical doctor shall be a practicing physician who has practiced” for “Those recommended shall be practicing physicians who have practiced” in the second sentence; in (a)(iii), added the provision beginning with “shall be a resident” at the end; in (b), substituted “four (4) years, except that the expiring term of a member shall continue until a successor member has been appointed” for “three (3) years with initial terms for the physical therapist members being staggered so the term of one (1) physical therapist expires each year” in the first sentence and added the second sentence; and in (c), substituted “compensation at the salary rate provided in W.S. 28-5-101(d)” for “fifty dollars ($50.00).”

The 2014 amendment, effective July 1, 2014, in (c), substituted “as provided in W.S. 33-1-302(a)(vii)” for “allowance as allowed to state employees” in the first sentence.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-25-101(a)(xii).

§ 33-25-104. Board of physical therapy; powers and duties generally.

  1. The board shall have the following powers and duties:
    1. Evaluate the qualifications of applicants for licensure and certification, conduct examinations for applicants, issue license or registration certificates to those who meet the requirements established by the board;
    2. Revoke, suspend, restrict, condition, reprimand, refuse to renew or refuse to issue the license of any physical therapist or the certificate of any physical therapy assistant or applicant pursuant to W.S. 33-25-111 ;
    3. Maintain current records listing the name of every licensed physical therapist and certified physical therapist assistant in this state, his business and home address, the date and number of his license or certification and, if known, his area or expertise, professional interest or credentials;
      1. Repealed by Laws 2009, ch. 134, § 3.
    4. Adopt rules and regulations to implement this act;
    5. Within the limitations provided in W.S. 33-25-113(a), set and from time to time revise fees as necessary to recover the expenses of administering this act;
    6. Establish procedures for assessing the continuing professional competence of physical therapists and physical therapist assistants, including continuing education requirements that ensure that licensees’ knowledge and abilities reflect current practices and technology;
    7. Conduct investigations, hearings and proceedings concerning alleged violations of this act and board rules and regulations;
    8. Inspect or duplicate patient medical records which relate to any alleged acts of misconduct, documented in the form of a formal complaint filed with the board, against any license or certificate holder and as authorized by the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act for regulatory bodies;
    9. Report final disciplinary action taken against a license or certificate holder to the extent authorized or required by other state and federal laws.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 4; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.4; Laws 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 2009, ch. 134, §§ 2, 3.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a)(i), substituted “Evaluate the qualifications of applicants for licensure and certification” for “Pass upon the qualifications of applicants for license as a physical therapist and registration as a physical therapist assistant”; in (a)(ii), deleted “Have authority to” from the beginning, substituted “restrict, condition, reprimand, refuse to renew or refuse to issue” for “or deny”, and substituted “certification” for “registration”; repealed (a)(iii)(A), which read “This list shall be published and revised each year. Copies shall be available to any person”; and added (a)(vi) through (a)(ix).

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-25-101(a)(xii).

§ 33-25-105. License and certification requirements; foreign trained applicants.

  1. Application for licensure as a physical therapist shall be made on forms prescribed by the board, presenting to the satisfaction of the board the following:
    1. Evidence through the application or otherwise, as the board deems desirable with due regard to the paramount interests of the public, as to the honesty, truthfulness, integrity and competency of the applicant;
    2. Evidence of graduation from an accredited program of physical therapy or physical therapy assistant education as set forth in rules and regulations;
    3. A personal interview if requested by the board;
    4. If not exempted under W.S. 33-25-108 , receipt of a passing score on a physical therapy examination as set forth in board rules and regulations.
  2. A physical therapist applicant whose application is based on a diploma issued to him by a physical therapy school outside the United States shall:
    1. Complete the application forms and pay the application fee prescribed by rules of the board;
    2. Furnish evidence satisfactory to the board of the completion of a physical therapy school resident course of professional instruction substantially equivalent to that required in paragraph (a)(ii) of this section. A professional education program accredited by the same accrediting agency approved by the board for programs within the United States shall be deemed substantially equivalent. In all other instances, “substantially equivalent” means a program that:
      1. Prepares the applicant to engage in the practice of physical therapy without restriction;
      2. Is recognized by the ministry of education of the country in which it is located.
    3. Undergo a credentials evaluation directed by the board which determines the applicant has met the uniform criteria for educational requirements prescribed by board rules;
    4. Complete any additional education required by the board;
    5. Pass a board approved English proficiency examination if the applicant’s native language is not English;
    6. If not exempted under W.S. 33-25-108 , receive a passing score on an examination approved by the board and prescribed by board rules;
    7. Attend a personal interview if requested by the board.
  3. An applicant for certification as a physical therapist assistant shall:
    1. Complete the application process including payment of fees;
    2. Submit proof of graduation from a physical therapist assistant education program accredited by a national accreditation agency approved by the board;
    3. If not exempted under W.S. 33-25-108 , receive a passing score on an examination approved by the board and prescribed by board rules;
    4. Meet with the board or a subcommittee of the board if requested.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 5; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.5; Laws 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 2009, ch. 134, § 2.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, substituted “licensure as a physical therapist” for “licensure or registration” in (a); in (a)(ii), substituted “graduation from an accredited” for “successful completion of a board approved” and inserted “education” following “physical therapy assistant”; rewrote (a)(iii), which read: “A personal interview may be required if the board deems it necessary”; added (a)(iv); in (b), designated the existing provisions beginning with “furnish evidence” as (b)(ii) and added (b)(i); in (b)(ii), substituted “substantially equivalent” for “equivalent” in the first sentence, deleted the former second through fourth sentences, which dealt with requirements for foreign applicants, and added the present second and third sentences; added (b)(ii)(A) and (b)(ii)(B); added (b)(iii) through (b)(vii); and added (c).

§ 33-25-106. Examinations.

  1. All applicants shall be required to pass an examination prior to their being licensed or certified as provided in this article unless otherwise exempted from examination pursuant to W.S. 33-25-108 . The examinations shall be approved by the board.
  2. through (d) Repealed by Laws 2009, ch. 134, § 3.
  3. The physical therapist examination shall be a national examination which tests entry level competence related to physical therapy theory, examination and evaluation, diagnosis, prognosis, treatment intervention, prevention and consultation.
  4. The physical therapy assistant examination shall test for requisite knowledge and skills in the technical application of physical therapy.
  5. If the board determines that an applicant has engaged in or attempted to engage in conduct that subverts or undermines the integrity of the examination process, the board may disqualify the applicant from taking or retaking the examination for a specified period of time.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 6; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.6; Laws 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 2009, ch. 134, §§ 2, 3.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a), in the first sentence, substituted “certified” for “registered” and substituted “in this article” for “herein”, in the second sentence, substituted “examinations” for “examination”, deleted “and administered” following “approved”, and deleted “and shall include a written examination which shall test each applicant's knowledge of basic and clinical sciences as they relate to physical therapy and physical therapy theory and physical therapy procedures along with such other subjects as the board may deem useful to test the applicant's fitness to practice physical therapy or to act as physical therapy assistant” from the end, and deleted the third sentence, which read: “The board shall define passing and failing examination grades”; repealed (b), which read: “Examinations shall be held at such times and places as the board shall determine”; repealed (c), which read: “The board may appoint persons to conduct the examinations”; repealed (d), which dealt with retaking examinations; and added (e), (f) and (g).

§ 33-25-107. License; certificate of registration.

  1. The board shall issue a license or certificate to each applicant who meets the requirements for licensure or certification without examination or who passes the examination and meets the standards established herein for licensure or certification.
  2. Each individual licensed as a physical therapist in this state is authorized to use the letters “P.T.” after his name, and may represent himself to the public as a licensed physical therapist.
  3. Each individual certified as a physical therapist assistant shall be entitled to use the letters “P.T.A.” after his name, and may represent himself to the public as a certified physical therapist assistant.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 7; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.7; Laws 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 2009, ch. 134, § 2.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a), deleted “of registration” following “certificate” and substituted “certification” for “registration” in two places; deleted “‘L.P.T.’ or” preceding “‘P.T.’” in (b); and in (c), substituted “certified” for “registered” in two places and deleted “‘L.P.T.A.’ or” preceding “‘P.T.A.’”

§ 33-25-108. Licensure or certification by endorsement.

  1. The board shall license as a physical therapist or certify as a physical therapist assistant without examination an applicant who:
    1. Submits a complete application for licensure or certification by endorsement including payment of all applicable fees;
    2. Provides verification that the applicant is licensed or registered without restriction as a physical therapist or licensed, registered or certified without restriction as a physical therapist assistant by another jurisdiction;
    3. Demonstrates that the requirements for license, registration or certification in the other jurisdiction were, at the date of licensure or registration, substantially equal to the requirements for licensing or certification in this act;
    4. Has not had any professional discipline and is not subject to any investigation or pending disciplinary action in any other jurisdiction;
    5. Meets with the board or a subcommittee of the board if requested.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 8; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.8; Laws 1971, ch. 172, § 3; 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 2009, ch. 134, § 2.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, designated the existing provisions beginning with “The board shall license” as (a), designated the existing provisions beginning with “licensed or registered” as (a)(ii), and designated the existing provisions beginning with “requirements for license” as (a)(iii); in (a), inserted “as a physical therapist” following “shall license”, substituted “certify as a physical therapist assistant” for “register”, and substituted “an applicant who” for “those applicants who meet the requirements set forth in W.S. 33 25 108 and who are”; added (a)(i); in (a)(ii), added “Provides verification that the applicant is” at the beginning, added “without restriction” following “certified”, and substituted “another jurisdiction for “another state or territory of the United States or the District of Columbia if the”; in (a)(iii), added “Demonstrates that the” at the beginning, substituted “other jurisdiction” for “state, territory or district”, substituted “certification in this act” for “registration set forth in this act”, and deleted the second sentence, which read: “However, if the applicant has not taken a physical therapy examination given by the professional examination service, or has failed the examination one (1) or more times, issuance of a license or registration under this section is at the discretion of the board”, and added (a)(iv) and (a)(v).

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-25-101(a)(xii).

§ 33-25-109. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2009, ch. 134, § 3.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 9, related to temporary license to practice physical therapy.

§ 33-25-110. License or certificate expiration and reissuance.

  1. All permanent licenses and certificates issued pursuant to this act shall expire on October 1 of the year next succeeding their issuance.
  2. A license or certificate may be renewed by submitting a timely, sufficient and complete application, payment of the required fee and verification of continuing competence.
  3. A license or certificate which has expired may be reissued upon submission by the applicant of a completed application, payment of fees, demonstration that the applicant meets all current requirements for licensure or certification under this act and verification of continuing competence.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 10; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.10; Laws 1971, ch. 172, § 5; 1976, ch. 14, § 1; 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 2009, ch. 134, § 2.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, deleted “of registration” following “certificate” throughout the section; designated the existing provisions beginning with “All permanent licenses” as (a), designated the existing provisions beginning with “A license or certificate may be renewed” as (b), and designated the existing provisions beginning with “A license or certificate which has expired” as (c); substituted “October 1” for “January 1” in (a); in (b), substituted “submitting a timely, sufficient and complete application” for “making application”, deleted “and upon” preceding “payment”, and added “and verification of continuing competence” at the end; and substituted “reissued upon submission by the applicant of a completed application, payment of fees, demonstration that the applicant meets all current requirements for licensure or certification under this act and verification of continuing competence” for “renewed within five (5) years of its expiration by the payment of renewal fees for each year or part thereof during which the license or registration was ineffective, and the payment of the required restoration fee. No renewal shall be permitted of a license or certificate of registration which has expired and has not been renewed for five (5) years from its expiration date, without full compliance with all requirements of this act” in (c).

Meaning of “this act.” —

For definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-25-101(a)(xii).

§ 33-25-111. Discipline; denial or suspension of license or certificate; grounds.

  1. The board may revoke, suspend, restrict, condition, reprimand, refuse to issue or refuse to renew the license or certification of any individual who:
    1. Practices physical therapy or acts as a physical therapist assistant in violation of the provisions of this act;
    2. Has practiced or attempts to practice fraud or deceit in:
      1. Procuring or attempting to procure a license or certificate;
      2. Filing or reporting any health care information, including but not limited to client documentation, agency records or other essential health documents;
      3. Signing any report or record as a physical therapist or physical therapist assistant;
      4. Representing authority to practice physical therapy;
      5. Submitting any information or record to the board.
    3. Commits negligence or incompetence in the practice of physical therapy or engages in any act inconsistent with uniform and reasonable standards of physical therapy practice as defined by board rules and regulations, whether with or without injury to a patient;
    4. Has been convicted of a felony or a misdemeanor that relates adversely to the practice of physical therapy or the ability to practice physical therapy, in the courts of this state, another jurisdiction or another country. As used in this paragraph, conviction includes a finding or verdict of guilt, an admission of guilt, a plea of nolo contendere or a plea agreement where the defendant has pled guilty yet not admitted to all the facts that comprise the crime;
    5. Unlawfully uses or possesses controlled substances, or excessively indulges in the use of alcoholic beverages;
    6. Has treated or has undertaken to treat human ailments otherwise than by physical therapy as defined in this act;
    7. Has had his license to practice physical therapy or certification to act as a physical therapist assistant refused, revoked or suspended or has had other disciplinary action taken in another jurisdiction or country;
    8. Has negligently failed to refer a patient whose condition is beyond the training or ability of the physical therapist to another professional qualified to diagnose or care for the condition;
    9. Has engaged in any conduct or practice contrary to recognized standards of ethics of the physical therapy profession where the conduct or practice might constitute a danger to the health, safety or welfare of the patient or the public;
    10. Engages directly or indirectly in the division, transferring, assigning, rebating, or refunding of fees received for professional services or profits by means of a credit or other valuable consideration as an unearned commission, discount or gratuity with any person who has referred a patient, or with any relative or business associate of the referring person. Nothing in this paragraph shall be construed as prohibiting the members of any regularly and properly organized business entity comprised of or including physical therapists from making any division of their total fees among themselves as they determine by contract necessary;
    11. Has been judged mentally incompetent by a court of competent jurisdiction;
    12. Fails to refer a patient or client or post information as required by W.S. 33-25-102(c) and (e);
    13. Has knowingly engaged in an act which the license or certificate holder knew was beyond the scope of the individual’s license or certificate or performed acts without sufficient education, knowledge or ability to competently apply physical therapy principles and skills;
    14. Is unfit or incompetent to practice physical therapy by reason of negligence, habits or other causes including but not limited to inability to exercise reasonable skill and care for patients by reasons of physical disability, mental disability or the use of drugs, narcotics, alcohol, chemicals or other substance that affects mental faculties;
    15. Knowingly fails to report to the board any violation of this act or rules and regulations of the board;
    16. Violates any provisions of this act, rules and regulations of the board or lawfully issued disciplinary order of the board;
    17. Has engaged or attempted to engage in conduct that subverts or undermines the integrity of the examination or the examination process including but not limited to utilizing recalled or memorized examination questions, failing to comply with all test center security procedures, communicating with other examinees during the examination or copying or sharing examination questions or portions of questions;
    18. Has failed to maintain adequate patient records that include identification of the patient, evaluation of objective findings, a diagnosis, a plan of care, a treatment record and a discharge plan;
    19. Has failed to properly supervise physical therapist assistants or physical therapy aides;
    20. Repealed by Laws 2018, ch. 80, §  3.
    21. Has interfered with an investigation or disciplinary proceeding by:
      1. Failing to provide the board with requested information or documents, including patient medical records;
      2. Misrepresentation of material facts;
      3. Threatening, harassing or intimidating any patient, witness or board member during the course of an investigation.
    22. Has failed to maintain patient confidentiality, including confidentiality of records relating to consultation by telecommunication, without documented patient authorization or as otherwise required by law.
  2. Upon receipt from the department of family services of a certified copy of an order from a court to withhold, suspend or otherwise restrict a license issued by the board, the board shall notify the party named in the court order of the withholding, suspension or restriction of the license in accordance with the terms of the court order. No appeal under the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act shall be allowed for a license withheld, suspended or restricted under this subsection.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 11; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.11; Laws 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 1997, ch. 128, § 2; 2003, ch. 111, § 1; 2009, ch. 134, § 2; 2018, ch. 80, § 3; 2019, ch. 12, § 1.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, substituted “certification” for “registration” in (a) and (a)(vii); in (a), deleted “limit the scope of practice allowed by the license or registration, or condition the retention of a license or registration upon successful completion of any reasonable requirement, or may refuse to license or register any applicant or may refuse to renew the license or registration of any person or may suspend or” following “the board may” and added “suspend, restrict, condition, reprimand, refuse to issue or refuse to renew” preceding “the license”; rewrote (a)(ii), which read: “Attempts to or obtains licensure or registration by fraud or misrepresentations”; added (a)(ii)(A) through (a)(ii)(E); added the provision beginning with “or engages” in (a)(iii); in (a)(iv), in the first sentence, added “or a misdemeanor that relates adversely to the practice of physical therapy or the ability to practice physical therapy” following “a felony” and substituted “another jurisdiction or another country” for “or any other state, territory or country”, and in the second sentence, added the language beginning with “or a plea agreement”; in (a)(v), substituted “Unlawfully uses or possesses” for “Habitually indulges in the use of” and substituted “alcoholic beverages” for “alcoholic liquors or malt beverages”; substituted “in another jurisdiction” for “by the proper authorities of another state, territory” in (a)(vii); substituted “Has engaged in” for “Has been guilty of” in (a)(ix); substituted “33-25-102(e)” for “33-25-102(c) and (e)” in (a)(xii); and added (a)(xiii) through (a)(xxii).

The 2018 amendment, effective July 1, 2018, repealed former (a)(xx), which read: “Has engaged in sexual misconduct as defined by the rules and regulations of the board.”

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, in (a)(xii) substituted "33-25-102(c) and (e);" for "33-25-102(e)".

Meaning of “this act.” —

For definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-25-101(a)(xii).

§ 33-25-112. Hearing and appeal procedures.

  1. All disciplinary actions, denials of applications and hearings shall be conducted in accordance with the provisions of the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act.
  2. Except as provided by W.S. 33-25-111(b), all board decisions concerning revocation or suspension of a license or registration shall require an affirmative vote of three (3) board members.
  3. In any appeal procedure the board shall be represented by an attorney from the staff of the attorney general.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 12; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.12; Laws 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 1997, ch. 128, § 2; 2009, ch. 134, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to judicial review of administrative action, see Rule 12, W.R.A.P.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a), deleted the former first through third sentences, which dealt with the board’s duties of notification in cases of denials, suspensions or revocations of licenses or in case of complaints; and in the present first sentence, substituted “All disciplinary actions, denials of applications and hearings” for “The hearing”.

Law reviews. —

For article, “Administrative Law, Wyoming Style,” see XVIII Land & Water L. Rev. 223 (1983).

§ 33-25-113. Fees.

  1. The board, pursuant to W.S. 33-1-201 , shall establish fees for examination, licensure or certification, licensure or certification by endorsement, renewal and reissuance.
  2. All money shall be received and collected as provided by law. The state treasurer shall credit the money to a separate account which is subject at all times to the warrant of the state auditor, drawn upon written requisition of the president, and attested by the secretary of the board of physical therapy, with seal attached, for the payment of any expenses made by the board.
  3. Repealed by Laws 1985, ch. 216, § 3.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 13; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.13; Laws 1971, ch. 172, § 6; 1973, ch. 245, § 3; 1976, ch. 14, § 1; 1985, ch. 216, §§ 2, 3; 1992, ch. 56, § 2; 2005, ch. 231, § 1; 2009, ch. 134, § 2.

Cross references. —

For present provision relating to payment to board members of per diem and mileage allowance, see § 33-25-103(c).

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, substituted “a separate account” for “an account within the earmarked revenue fund” in (b).

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a), substituted “certification, licensure or certification by endorsement” for “registration without examination, temporary licensure or registration” and substituted “reissuance” for “restoration.”

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2005, ch. 231, § 3, provides: “The provisions of this act shall supersede the provisions of any other bill enacted into law during the 2005 general session which amends or references accounts or funds to the extent any other enactment is inconsistent with the establishment of the funds and accounts created under this act. The state auditor shall account for any fund or account created in any other legislation enacted in the 2005 general session in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) as promulgated by the governmental accounting standards board (GASB) and in accordance with this act.”

§ 33-25-114. Penalties.

Each violation of any provision of this act is a misdemeanor and is punishable by fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) or by imprisonment for not more than six (6) months, or both.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 131, § 14; W.S. 1957, § 33-326.14; Laws 1985, ch. 216, § 2; 2009, ch. 134, § 2.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, inserted “any provision of” preceding “this act” and inserted “is a misdemeanor and” preceding “is punishable.”

Meaning of “this act.” —

For definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-25-101(a)(xii).

§ 33-25-115. Actions against board members; defense.

  1. Members, agents and employees of the board and any person reporting information to the board under oath shall be immune from personal liability with respect to acts done and actions taken in good faith without fraud or malice.
  2. The immunity provided by this section shall extend to the members of any professional review committee, investigators and witnesses appearing before the board.
  3. The state shall defend and hold harmless any member of the board from any action at law resulting from any action taken in good faith in the course of his official duties.

History. Laws 1985, ch. 216, § 1; 2009, ch. 134, § 2.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, designated the existing language as (c) and added (a) and (b).

§ 33-25-116. Injunctive relief; grounds.

  1. The board may petition in its own name for an injunction to an appropriate court to enjoin:
    1. Any person violating W.S. 33-25-102(a), unless specifically exempt from licensure or certification pursuant to W.S. 33-25-102(f);
    2. Any license or certificate holder who is in violation of this act from practicing physical therapy;
    3. Any person, firm, corporation, institution, association, business or other entity from employing any individual to practice physical therapy who is not licensed or certified as required by this act.

History. Laws 2009, ch. 134, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-25-101(a)(xii).

Effective dates. —

Laws 2009, ch. 134, § 4, makes the act effective July 1, 2009.

Chapter 26 Physicians and Surgeons

  • Article 1. General Provisions

  • Article 3. Licensing
  • Article 4. Investigations and Disciplinary Proceedings
  • Article 5. Physicians Assistants
  • Article 6. Volunteer Physicians and Physician Assistants
  • Article 7. Interstate Medical Licensure Compact

Cross references. —

As to licensing provisions generally, see chapter 1 of this title.

As to podiatrists, see chapter 9 of this title.

As to inapplicability of chapter 9 of this title (relative to podiatrists) to physicians and surgeons, see § 33-9-109 .

As to chiropractors, see chapter 10 of this title.

For provision declaring the practice of chiropractics not to be the practice of medicine, surgery or osteopathy, see § 33-10-117 .

As to dentists and dental hygienists, see chapter 15 of this title.

As to inapplicability of chapter 15 of this title (relating to dentists) to legally qualified medical doctors, see § 33-15-115 .

As to nurses, see chapter 21 of this title.

As to optometrists, see chapter 23 of this title.

As to exemption from regulations concerning optometrists, see § 33-23-101 .

For the Wyoming Pharmacy Act, see chapter 24 of this title.

As to physical therapists, see chapter 25 of this title.

As to eye care practitioners, see chapter 32 of this title.

As to speech pathologists and audiologists, see chapter 33 of this title.

As to exemption of physicians and surgeons from License Act for Speech Pathologists and Audiologists, see § 33-33-104 .

As to licensing of clinical laboratories and blood banks, see chapter 34 of this title.

As to hearing aid specialist licensure, see chapter 35 of this title.

As to exemption of physicians from hearing aid specialists licensing provisions, see § 33-35-106 .

For the Wyoming Emergency Medical Services Act, see chapter 36 of this title.

As to privileged communication by a licensed or certified mental health professional, see § 33-38-113 .

As to immunity from liability for volunteer health care professionals, see § 1-1-129 .

For duties of physicians as to public health and safety generally, see title 35.

Revision of chapter. —

Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1, revised this chapter by repealing and recreating former §§ 33-26-101 through 33-26-142 as present §§ 33-26-101 through 33-26-511 .

Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 2, renumbered former § 33-26-143 as present § 1-1-120 .

Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 3, renumbered former §§ 33-26-144 through 33-26-152 as present §§ 35-22-101 through 35-22-109 .

Former § 33-26-102 was also amended by ch. 175, § 1. This amendment was not given effect due to the 1987 revision of this chapter.

No detailed explanation of the changes made by Laws 1987, ch. 79 has been attempted, but, where appropriate, annotations to cases decided under former provisions have been placed under comparable sections. For tables of revised and renumbered sections, see Volume 11 of the Wyoming Statutes Annotated.

Constitutionality of chapter. —

This section does not violate art. 3, § 26, Wyo. Const.State v. Pitet, 69 Wyo. 478, 243 P.2d 177, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1952).

To declare unconstitutional this chapter, having to do with the medical profession and its regulation, would be a serious thing and to do so there must be ample and good reason. The objection should be grave and the conflict between it and the constitution substantial. State v. Pitet, 69 Wyo. 478, 243 P.2d 177, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1952).

This chapter, as ch. 45, Laws 1905, with the title “Board of Medical Examiners xxx,” did not violate art. 3, §§ 24 and 26, Wyo. Const., although 4 sections thereof did not refer to or mention the board of medical examiners, since they were considered germane to the general object of the law as expressed in the title. State v. Pitet, 69 Wyo. 478, 243 P.2d 177, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1952).

This chapter, as ch. 45, Laws 1905, was incorporated in the Revised Statutes of 1931, a general revision of laws held to be within the provisions of art. 3, § 24, Wyo. Const., and was validated by that incorporation in a properly revised code, even if it was unconstitutional when originally passed. State v. Pitet, 69 Wyo. 478, 243 P.2d 177, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1952).

Applied in

Taylor v. Wyoming Bd. of Medicine, 930 P.2d 973, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1996).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Liability of anesthetist for injuries from spinal anesthetics, 90 ALR3d 775.

Patient's right to refuse treatment allegedly necessary to sustain life, 93 ALR3d 67.

Malpractice in connection with electroshock treatment, 94 ALR3d 317.

Physician's liability for causing patient to become addicted to drugs, 16 ALR4th 999.

Applicability of doctrine of strict liability in tort to injury resulting from X-ray radiation, 16 ALR4th 1300.

Liability of doctor, psychiatrist or psychologist for failure to take steps to prevent patient's suicide, 17 ALR4th 1128.

Liability for wrongful autopsy, 18 ALR4th 858.

Physician's tort liability for unauthorized disclosure of confidential information about patient, 48 ALR4th 668.

Medical malpractice: presumption or inference from failure of hospital or doctor to produce relevant medical records, 69 ALR4th 906.

Liability of hospital, physician or other medical personnel for death or injury to mother or child caused by improper procedures during cesarean delivery, 76 ALR4th 1112.

Physician's use of patient's tissues, cells or bodily substances for medical research or economic purposes, 16 ALR5th 143.

Medical malpractice in connection with breast augmentation, reduction or reconstruction, 28 ALR5th 497.

Psychotherapist-patient privilege under federal common law, 72 ALR Fed 395.

Article 1. General Provisions

  • § 33-26-101.  Short title.
  • § 33-26-102.  Definitions. [Effective until January 1, 2022]
  • § 33-26-102.  Definitions. [Effective January 1, 2022]
  • § 33-26-103.  Applicability of chapter.

§ 33-26-101. Short title.

This chapter is known and may be cited as the “Medical Practice Act”.

History. Laws 1976, ch. 24, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 33-340.2; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-128; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, § 1.

Naturopathy is simply one of the methods of practicing medicine. —

The practice of what is now called naturopathy has from time immemorial, at least to the extent then known, been considered simply as an integral part of the practice of medicine. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

It cannot be regarded as a separate and distinct profession. —

Our statute is clear, that the practice of naturopathy cannot be regarded as a separate and distinct profession like that of dentistry for instance, nor can any good reason be given why the legislature may not for the benefit of society require that those who practice the healing art should know and keep up with the improvements and advanced learning in that art. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

And legislature had perfect right to refuse to make special regulations. —

It is true that the legislature has licensed dentists and chiropractors and other persons who in some manner attempt to exercise part of the healing art, but simply because the legislature made special regulations for these groups did not require it to make similar regulations concerning naturopaths. It had a perfect right to refuse to provide such regulations relating to them. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

And require practitioner to have been admitted to practice as a physician or surgeon. —

The health and well-being of the members of society is too important to justify the failure to make requirements commensurate with the advancement of civilization. There is nothing to prohibit the practice of naturopathy provided that under our statute the practitioner has the learning of a physician and surgeon and has been admitted to practice as such in this state. Such a requirement is valid. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

Scope of license to practice medicine or surgery. —

The practice of medicine, in its broadest sense, is the art of healing disease and preserving health, and the license to practice medicine or surgery generally entitles the licensee to practice medicine or surgery in all the various branches and to use any method for treatment and healing human ailments, although others may be authorized to practice in limited fields of the general practice. State v. Catellier, 63 Wyo. 123, 179 P.2d 203, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1947).

Exceeding scope of license as violation. —

A person licensed as a chiropodist who administered a general anesthetic and set a dislocated shoulder was held to have violated this section, defining the practice of medicine. State v. Catellier, 63 Wyo. 123, 179 P.2d 203, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1947).

Prohibited practices. —

Practicing medicine and receiving compensation therefor and practicing medicine without a license are separate offenses under this section. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

Matter of sentence in discretion of trial court. —

Matter of sentence in a prosecution under this section for practicing without a license is addressed to the sound discretion of trial court. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

Cited in

Johnson v. State ex rel. Wyoming Bd. of Medicine, 986 P.2d 157, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 127 (Wyo. 1999).

Law reviews. —

See note, “What Constitutes the Practice of Medicine in Wyoming,” 13 Wyo. L.J. 259.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Constitutionality and construction of statutes or regulations prohibiting one who has no license to practice medicine from owning, maintaining, or operating an office therefor, 20 ALR2d 808.

Illegal practice of medicine under statute, ordinance, or other measure involving chemical treatment of public water supply, 43 ALR2d 453.

Hypnotism as illegal practice of medicine, 85 ALR2d 1128.

Single or isolated transaction as falling within provisions of licensing requirements, 93 ALR2d 90.

Practicing medicine, surgery, dentistry, optometry, podiatry, or other healing arts without license as a separate or continuing offense, 99 ALR2d 654.

Acupuncture as illegal practice of medicine, 72 ALR3d 1257.

Right of medical patient to obtain, or physician to prescribe, Laetrile for treatment of illness — state cases, 5 ALR4th 219.

Regulation of practice of acupuncture, 17 ALR4th 964.

Standard of care owed to patient by medical specialist as determined by local, “like community,” state, national, or other standards, 18 ALR4th 603.

Medical malpractice: Who are “health care providers,” or the like, whose actions fall within statutes specifically governing actions and damages for medical malpractice, 12 ALR5th 1.

Validity, construction and application of state statutory provisions limiting amount of recovery in medical malpractice claims, 26 ALR5th 245.

Coverage of professional liability or indemnity policy for sexual contact with patients by physicians, surgeons, and other healers, 60 ALR5th 239.

§ 33-26-102. Definitions. [Effective until January 1, 2022]

  1. As used in this chapter:
    1. Repealed by Laws 1991, ch. 143, § 2.
    2. “A.O.A.” means the American Osteopathic Association;
    3. “Board” means the Wyoming state board of medicine;
    4. “Errant conduct” means conduct by a licensee which may constitute grounds for discipline as set forth in this act;
    5. “Repealed by Laws 1991, ch. 143, § 2.
    6. “Health care entity” means any hospital, clinic, training program, professional society or committee of physicians or other licensed health care practitioners that follows a peer review process for the purpose of furthering quality health care;
    7. “Impaired” means a person who is unable to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety to patients by reason of one (1) or more of the following:
      1. Medical incompetence;
      2. Mental illness;
      3. Physical illness, including but not limited to deterioration through the aging process or loss of motor skill;
      4. Chemical or alcohol impairment, addiction, dependence or abuse.
    8. “Lapsed” means the status of a license when the licensee fails to renew the license by July 1 of any year or when the holder of a temporary license fails to appear for an interview at the next board meeting following the date of issuance or fails to submit a written request for extension of a temporary license or when a written request for extension is not approved by the board;
    9. “License” means a license to practice medicine in this state issued by the board pursuant to this chapter;
    10. “Licensee” means any person licensed by the board under this chapter;
    11. “Practicing medicine” means any person who in any manner:
      1. Advertises, holds out, or represents to the public that he is authorized to practice medicine in this state; or
      2. Offers or undertakes to prevent, diagnose, correct or treat, in any manner, by any means, method or device, any human disease, illness, pain, wound, fracture, infirmity, defect or abnormal physical or mental condition, injury, deformity or ailment, including the management of pregnancy and parturition; or
      3. Attaches the title of M.D., D.O., physician, surgeon, osteopathic physician or osteopathic surgeon, doctor, or any other words, letters or abbreviations or any combination thereof when used in the conduct of any occupation or profession pertaining to the prevention, diagnosis or treatment of human disease or condition unless the designation additionally contains the description of another branch of the healing arts for which one holds a valid license in this state; or
      4. Practices osteopathy; or
      5. Offers or undertakes to prescribe, order, give or administer drugs which can only be obtained by prescription according to law; or
      6. Renders a determination of medical necessity or appropriateness of proposed treatment.
    12. “Reactivation” after a license has lapsed means the completion of all requirements set forth in W.S. 33-26-305(c);
    13. Repealed by Laws 2018, ch. 80, §  3.
    14. “USMLE” means the United States medical licensing examination;
    15. “L.C.M.E.” means the liaison committee on medical education;
    16. “A.C.G.M.E.” means accreditation council for graduate medical education;
    17. “Fifth pathway” means an academic year of supervised clinical education provided by an L.C.M.E. accredited medical school to students who have:
      1. Repealed by Laws 2003, ch. 190, § 3.
      2. Studied at a medical school outside of the United States, Puerto Rico or Canada;
      3. Completed all of the formal requirements of the foreign medical school, except internship or social service;
      4. Attained a score satisfactory to the sponsoring medical school on a screening examination; and
      5. Passed the foreign medical graduate examination in the medical sciences, parts I and II of the examination of the national board of medical examiners, or steps 1 and 2 of the USMLE.
    18. “FLEX examination” means the federation of state medical boards licensing examination;
    19. “R.C.P.S.C.” means the royal college of physicians and surgeons of Canada;
    20. “Physician-patient relationship” means a relationship between a licensee and any person formed for the purpose of the licensee providing medical diagnosis or treatment to the person, whether or not for compensation;
    21. “This act” means the Medical Practice Act;
    22. “Board counsel” means an attorney designated by the board to provide legal counsel to the board and its staff in the conduct of the board’s business;
    23. “Board prosecutor” means an attorney designated by the board to prosecute, and to provide legal counsel to interviewers and petitioners in, disciplinary cases pending before the board pursuant to this act and the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act;
    24. “COMLEX” means the comprehensive osteopathic medical licensing examination, administered by the national board of osteopathic medical examiners;
    25. “Condition” means a specific requirement or prohibition imposed by any medical licensing board of any jurisdiction, or by any health care facility on an applicant’s or licensee’s clinical privileges at that facility, that shall be fulfilled by an applicant or licensee in order to obtain or continue to hold a license in that jurisdiction, or clinical privileges at that facility;
    26. “E.C.F.M.G.” means the educational commission for foreign medical graduates;
    27. “Restriction” means a limitation placed by any medical licensing board of any jurisdiction on an applicant’s or licensee’s scope of practice in that jurisdiction, or by any health care facility on an applicant’s or licensee’s clinical privileges at that facility;
    28. “SPEX examination” means the federation of state medical boards special purpose post-licensure competency examination;
    29. “Telemedicine” means the practice of medicine by electronic communication or other means from a physician in a location to a patient in another location, with or without an intervening health care provider.

History. Laws 1905, ch. 45, § 7; C.S. 1910, § 2871; C.S. 1920, § 3519; R.S. 1931, § 86-107; C.S. 1945, § 37-2007; W.S. 1957, § 33-327; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-101 ; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, §§ 1, 2; 1995, ch. 129, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, §§ 2, 3; 2009, ch. 201, § 1; 2018, ch. 80, § 3; 2021, ch. 81, § 2.

The 2009 amendment, substituted “who is unable to” for “who cannot” in (a)(vii); rewrote (a)(vii)(D) which read “Chemical impairment”; substituted “licensing examination” for “post-licensure competency examination” at the end of (a)(xviii); added (a)(xxii) through (a)(xxix); and made stylistic changes.

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

The 2018 amendment, effective July 1, 2018, repealed former (a)(xiii), which read: “‘Sexual misconduct’” means: (A) Any behavior by a licensee which involves offers of exchange of medical services for some form of sexual gratification; (B) Sexual contact that occurs concurrent with the physician-patient relationship; or (C) Any behavior by a licensee toward a patient, former patient, another licensee, an employee of a health care facility, an employee of the licensee or a relative or guardian of a patient that exploits the position of trust, knowledge, emotions or influence of the licensee.”

The 2021 amendment, effective January 1, 2022, in (a)(xi)(C), added "P.A.," and "physician assistant."

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Naturopathy is simply one of the methods of practicing medicine. —

The practice of what is now called naturopathy has from time immemorial, at least to the extent then known, been considered simply as an integral part of the practice of medicine. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

It cannot be regarded as a separate and distinct profession. —

Our statute is clear, that the practice of naturopathy cannot be regarded as a separate and distinct profession like that of dentistry for instance, nor can any good reason be given why the legislature may not for the benefit of society require that those who practice the healing art should know and keep up with the improvements and advanced learning in that art. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

And legislature had perfect right to refuse to make special regulations. —

It is true that the legislature has licensed dentists and chiropractors and other persons who in some manner attempt to exercise part of the healing art, but simply because the legislature made special regulations for these groups did not require it to make similar regulations concerning naturopaths. It had a perfect right to refuse to provide such regulations relating to them. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

And require practitioner to have been admitted to practice as a physician or surgeon. —

The health and well-being of the members of society is too important to justify the failure to make requirements commensurate with the advancement of civilization. There is nothing to prohibit the practice of naturopathy provided that under our statute the practitioner has the learning of a physician and surgeon and has been admitted to practice as such in this state. Such a requirement is valid. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

Chiropractor's use of clinical nutrition methods. A licensed chiropractor does not violate the Medical Practice Act by diagnosing a disease and by then treating the patient by the application of clinical nutritional methods; such practices constitute the practice of “chiropractic” under § 33-10-101 .Johnson v. State ex rel. Wyoming Bd. of Med., 986 P.2d 157, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 127 (Wyo. 1999).

Chiropractor who diagnosed and treated his grandson's strep throat with nutritional supplements was not “practicing medicine”. Johnson v. State ex rel. Wyoming Bd. of Med., 986 P.2d 157, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 127 (Wyo. 1999).

Dentist unauthorized to practice general nondental anesthesiology. —

A person licensed to practice dentistry in Wyoming who has special training and experience in the field of general anesthesia, but is not a licensed physician in Wyoming, is not authorized to practice general anesthesiology for nondental purposes. The restrictive language as used by the legislature in the Wyoming Dental Practice Act limits those licensed by that act to the practice of anesthesiology solely for purposes in connection with the oral cavity region. Also, the practice of general nondental anesthesiology is considered the “practice of medicine” as defined by the Paravecchio v. Memorial Hosp., 742 P.2d 1276, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 507 (Wyo. 1987), reh'g denied, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 523 (Wyo. Oct. 7, 1987), overruled in part, Torres v. State ex rel. Wyo. Workers' Safety & Comp. Div., 2004 WY 92, 95 P.3d 794, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 2004).

Scope of license to practice medicine or surgery. —

The practice of medicine, in its broadest sense, is the art of healing disease and preserving health, and the license to practice medicine or surgery generally entitles the licensee to practice medicine or surgery in all the various branches and to use any method for treatment and healing human ailments, although others may be authorized to practice in limited fields of the general practice. State v. Catellier, 63 Wyo. 123, 179 P.2d 203, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1947).

Exceeding scope of license as violation. —

A person licensed as a chiropodist who administered a general anesthetic and set a dislocated shoulder was held to have violated this section, defining the practice of medicine. State v. Catellier, 63 Wyo. 123, 179 P.2d 203, 1947 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1947).

Authorized use of term. —

A licensed chiropractor's use of the term “chiropractic physician” does not violate the Medical Practice Act. Johnson v. State ex rel. Wyoming Bd. of Medicine, 986 P.2d 157, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 127 (Wyo. 1999).

Prohibited practices. —

Practicing medicine and receiving compensation therefor and practicing medicine without a license are separate offenses under this section. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

Matter of sentence in discretion of trial court. —

Matter of sentence in a prosecution under this section for practicing without a license is addressed to the sound discretion of trial court. Hahn v. State, 78 Wyo. 258, 322 P.2d 896, 1958 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1958).

Stated in

Kirbens v. Wyoming State Bd. of Med., 992 P.2d 1056, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 209 (Wyo. 1999).

Law reviews. —

See note, “What Constitutes the Practice of Medicine in Wyoming,” 13 Wyo. L.J. 259.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Constitutionality and construction of statutes or regulations prohibiting one who has no license to practice medicine from owning, maintaining, or operating an office therefor, 20 ALR2d 808.

Illegal practice of medicine under statute, ordinance, or other measure involving chemical treatment of public water supply, 43 ALR2d 453.

Hypnotism as illegal practice of medicine, 85 ALR2d 1128.

Single or isolated transaction as falling within provisions of licensing requirements, 93 ALR2d 90.

Practicing medicine, surgery, dentistry, optometry, podiatry, or other healing arts without license as a separate or continuing offense, 99 ALR2d 654.

Acupuncture as illegal practice of medicine, 72 ALR3d 1257.

Right of medical patient to obtain, or physician to prescribe, Laetrile for treatment of illness, 5 ALR4th 219.

Regulation of practice of acupuncture, 17 ALR4th 964.

Standard of care owed to patient by medical specialist as determined by local, “like community,” state, national, or other standards, 18 ALR4th 603.

§ 33-26-102. Definitions. [Effective January 1, 2022]

  1. As used in this chapter:
    1. Repealed by Laws 1991, ch. 143, § 2.
    2. “A.O.A.” means the American Osteopathic Association;
    3. “Board” means the Wyoming state board of medicine;
    4. “Errant conduct” means conduct by a licensee which may constitute grounds for discipline as set forth in this act;
    5. “Repealed by Laws 1991, ch. 143, § 2.
    6. “Health care entity” means any hospital, clinic, training program, professional society or committee of physicians or other licensed health care practitioners that follows a peer review process for the purpose of furthering quality health care;
    7. “Impaired” means a person who is unable to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety to patients by reason of one (1) or more of the following:
      1. Medical incompetence;
      2. Mental illness;
      3. Physical illness, including but not limited to deterioration through the aging process or loss of motor skill;
      4. Chemical or alcohol impairment, addiction, dependence or abuse.
    8. “Lapsed” means the status of a license when the licensee fails to renew the license by July 1 of any year or when the holder of a temporary license fails to appear for an interview at the next board meeting following the date of issuance or fails to submit a written request for extension of a temporary license or when a written request for extension is not approved by the board;
    9. “License” means a license to practice medicine in this state issued by the board pursuant to this chapter;
    10. “Licensee” means any person licensed by the board under this chapter;
    11. “Practicing medicine” means any person who in any manner:
      1. Advertises, holds out, or represents to the public that he is authorized to practice medicine in this state; or
      2. Offers or undertakes to prevent, diagnose, correct or treat, in any manner, by any means, method or device, any human disease, illness, pain, wound, fracture, infirmity, defect or abnormal physical or mental condition, injury, deformity or ailment, including the management of pregnancy and parturition; or
      3. Attaches the title of M.D., D.O., P.A., physician, surgeon, osteopathic physician or osteopathic surgeon, doctor, physician assistant or any other words, letters or abbreviations or any combination thereof when used in the conduct of any occupation or profession pertaining to the prevention, diagnosis or treatment of human disease or condition unless the designation additionally contains the description of another branch of the healing arts for which one holds a valid license in this state; or
      4. Practices osteopathy; or
      5. Offers or undertakes to prescribe, order, give or administer drugs which can only be obtained by prescription according to law; or
      6. Renders a determination of medical necessity or appropriateness of proposed treatment.
    12. “Reactivation” after a license has lapsed means the completion of all requirements set forth in W.S. 33-26-305(c);
    13. Repealed by Laws 2018, ch. 80, §  3.
    14. “USMLE” means the United States medical licensing examination;
    15. “L.C.M.E.” means the liaison committee on medical education;
