    16. “A.C.G.M.E.” means accreditation council for graduate medical education;
    17. “Fifth pathway” means an academic year of supervised clinical education provided by an L.C.M.E. accredited medical school to students who have:
      1. Repealed by Laws 2003, ch. 190, § 3.
      2. Studied at a medical school outside of the United States, Puerto Rico or Canada;
      3. Completed all of the formal requirements of the foreign medical school, except internship or social service;
      4. Attained a score satisfactory to the sponsoring medical school on a screening examination; and
      5. Passed the foreign medical graduate examination in the medical sciences, parts I and II of the examination of the national board of medical examiners, or steps 1 and 2 of the USMLE.
    18. “FLEX examination” means the federation of state medical boards licensing examination;
    19. “R.C.P.S.C.” means the royal college of physicians and surgeons of Canada;
    20. “Physician-patient relationship” means a relationship between a licensee and any person formed for the purpose of the licensee providing medical diagnosis or treatment to the person, whether or not for compensation;
    21. “This act” means the Medical Practice Act;
    22. “Board counsel” means an attorney designated by the board to provide legal counsel to the board and its staff in the conduct of the board’s business;
    23. “Board prosecutor” means an attorney designated by the board to prosecute, and to provide legal counsel to interviewers and petitioners in, disciplinary cases pending before the board pursuant to this act and the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act;
    24. “COMLEX” means the comprehensive osteopathic medical licensing examination, administered by the national board of osteopathic medical examiners;
    25. “Condition” means a specific requirement or prohibition imposed by any medical licensing board of any jurisdiction, or by any health care facility on an applicant’s or licensee’s clinical privileges at that facility, that shall be fulfilled by an applicant or licensee in order to obtain or continue to hold a license in that jurisdiction, or clinical privileges at that facility;
    26. “E.C.F.M.G.” means the educational commission for foreign medical graduates;
    27. “Restriction” means a limitation placed by any medical licensing board of any jurisdiction on an applicant’s or licensee’s scope of practice in that jurisdiction, or by any health care facility on an applicant’s or licensee’s clinical privileges at that facility;
    28. “SPEX examination” means the federation of state medical boards special purpose post-licensure competency examination;
    29. “Telemedicine” means the practice of medicine by electronic communication or other means from a physician in a location to a patient in another location, with or without an intervening health care provider.

History. Laws 1905, ch. 45, § 7; C.S. 1910, § 2871; C.S. 1920, § 3519; R.S. 1931, § 86-107; C.S. 1945, § 37-2007; W.S. 1957, § 33-327; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-101 ; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, §§ 1, 2; 1995, ch. 129, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, §§ 2, 3; 2009, ch. 201, § 1; 2018, ch. 80, § 3; 2021, ch. 81, § 2.

§ 33-26-103. Applicability of chapter.

  1. This chapter does not apply to:
    1. Persons rendering medical assistance without compensation at the scene of an emergency;
    2. Medical students trained in an L.C.M.E. or A.O.A. accredited or board approved school of medicine serving as clinical clerks, residents or interns under the supervision of a physician licensed in this state;
    3. Commissioned medical officers of the United States armed services and medical officers of the United States public health service or the United States department of veterans affairs in the discharge of their official duties or within federally controlled facilities or enclaves, provided that the persons who are licensees of the board shall be subject to the provisions of this act and further provided that all such persons shall be the holder of a full and unrestricted license to practice medicine in one (1) or more jurisdictions of the United States;
    4. Any individual residing in and licensed in good standing to practice medicine in another state or country brought into this state for consultation by a physician licensed to practice medicine in this state, provided the physician licensed in this state notifies the board of the consultation in compliance with regulations adopted by the board;
    5. Any individual licensed to practice medicine in another state who comes to this state to remove human organs from brain-dead persons;
    6. The treatment of disease, injury, deformity or ailments by prayer or spiritual means provided that federal and state health and sanitation laws, rules and regulations are not violated;
    7. The gratuitous domestic administration of family remedies;
    8. Health care providers licensed under any other chapter of this title engaged in the practice of the profession for which he is licensed;
    9. Repealed by Laws 2003, ch. 190, § 3.
    10. Any person who does not represent himself to be a licensed health care professional who offers health care advice or nonprescription medicine to another person in a social or educational situation in any manner otherwise lawful.

History. Laws 1899, ch. 8, § 13; R.S. 1899, § 2201; Laws 1905, ch. 45, § 13; C.S. 1910, § 2877; C.S. 1920, § 3525; Laws 1925, ch. 126, § 4; 1931, ch. 34, § 1; R.S. 1931, § 86-113; C.S. 1945, § 37-2013; Laws 1957, ch. 142. § 3; W.S. 1957, § 33-341; Laws 1973, ch. 223, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-140; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1989, ch. 53, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, §§ 2, 3; 2004, ch. 130, § 1; 2009, ch. 201, § 1.

Cross references. —

For the Wyoming Emergency Medical Services Act, see chapter 36 of this title.

The 2004 amendment, in (a)(iii), substituted “service or” for “service of.”

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 19, 2004.

The 2009 amendment, substituted “United States Department of veterans affairs” for “veterans administration of the United States” in (a)(iii); and, in (a)(iv), inserted “in good standing,” substituted “brought into this state” for “called into this state,” and added the proviso at the end.

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-26-102(a)(xxi).

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Family remedy exemption. —

Mother's administration of nutritional supplements to her child as treatment for strep throat, as recommended by the child's chiropractor grandfather, together with the grandfather's reporting of that treatment to the school, were exempt from the Family Medical Practices Act under the family remedy exemption. Johnson v. State ex rel. Wyoming Bd. of Med., 986 P.2d 157, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 127 (Wyo. 1999).

Article 2. Wyoming State Board of Medicine

  • § 33-26-201.  State board of medicine; composition; appointment; terms; qualifications; removal; vacancies; quorum.
  • § 33-26-202.  Board; duties; general powers.
  • § 33-26-203.  Board; employment and salary of executive director; and other employees; compensation of members.

§ 33-26-201. State board of medicine; composition; appointment; terms; qualifications; removal; vacancies; quorum.

  1. The Wyoming state board of medicine shall consist of five (5) physicians licensed to practice medicine in Wyoming, not less than one (1) of whom shall possess the degree of doctor of osteopathy and not less than two (2) of whom shall possess the degree of doctor of medicine, one (1) physician assistant and two (2) lay members, appointed by the governor by and with the consent of the senate as required by W.S. 28-12-101 through 28-12-103 . Board members appointed by the governor shall serve at the pleasure of the governor. The board members shall annually elect a president, a vice-president, and a secretary.
  2. Board members shall serve four (4) year terms. No board member shall serve more than three (3) consecutive terms.
  3. Physician and physician assistant members shall reside in, hold a full and unrestricted license and actively practice in this state. Lay members shall reside in this state.
  4. The governor shall appoint a new board member if a vacancy occurs. A person appointed to fill a vacancy shall serve for the unexpired portion of the vacated term. A vacancy occurs if a member:
    1. Is absent from three (3) consecutive meetings;
    2. No longer holds a full and unrestricted license to practice in this state or no longer engages in active practice in this state;
    3. Resigns; or
    4. Is removed by the governor.
  5. A quorum of the board consists of five (5) board members, including a lay member, unless otherwise specified in subsection (f) of this section.
  6. If the board president determines that due to conflicts of interest or other circumstances it may not be possible to seat a quorum of board members to hear a disciplinary case brought pursuant to this act, the president may submit a written request to the governor for the appointment of one (1) or more acting board members to hear the disciplinary case in question. Upon receipt of the request, the governor shall appoint the requested number of temporary board members for the sole purpose of hearing the disciplinary case in question. Only persons who previously served as members of the board shall be eligible for temporary appointment to hear disciplinary cases before the board. Appointments made under this subsection shall not require the consent of the senate pursuant to W.S. 28-12-101 through 28-12-103 . Persons appointed pursuant to this subsection shall be compensated and have their expenses reimbursed in the same manner as regular board members under W.S. 33-26-203(c). The appointment of a person under this subsection shall automatically terminate upon the entering of a final order in the disciplinary case for which he was appointed.

History. Laws 1899, ch. 18, §§ 1, 2; R.S. 1899, §§ 2189, 2190; Laws 1905, ch. 45, §§ 1, 2; C.S. 1910, §§ 2865, 2866; Laws 1917, ch. 111, § 1; C.S. 1920, §§ 3513, 3514; R.S. 1931, §§ 86-101, 86-102; C.S. 1945, §§ 37-2001, 37-2002; Laws 1957, ch. 194, § 1; W.S. 1957, §§ 33-328, 33-329; Laws 1965, ch. 162, § 1; W.S. 1977, §§ 33-26-102 , 33-26-103 ; Laws 1979, ch. 17, § 2; 1981, ch. 78, § 1; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, § 1; 2001, ch. 166, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, § 2; 2009, ch. 201, § 1.

The 2009 amendment, substituted “not less than one (1) of whom shall possess the degree of doctor of osteopathy and not less than two (2) of whom shall possess the degree of doctor of medicine, one (1) physician assistant and two (2) lay members” for “one (1) of whom shall possess the degree of doctor of osteopathy, one (1) physician assistant and two (2) lay members not directly related to physicians” in (a); added “unless otherwise specified in subsection (f) of this section” at the end of (e); and added (f).

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-26-102(a)(xxi).

Presence of members. —

Conduct defined. —

Presence of members. —

Authorization to appoint temporary Wyoming Board of Medicine members does not suggest that members must be present in order to constitute a quorum. Painter v. Hallingbye, 2021 WY 78, 489 P.3d 684, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 86 (Wyo. 2021).

Conduct defined. —

Statute permits the Wyoming Board of Medicine president to petition the governor to appoint temporary members if the Board cannot seat a quorum to hear the case; because the term “conduct” does not require the Board to attend contested case hearings in person, the agency rules are not in conflict with the statute. Painter v. Hallingbye, 2021 WY 78, 489 P.3d 684, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 86 (Wyo. 2021).

§ 33-26-202. Board; duties; general powers.

  1. The board shall pass upon the qualifications and determine the fitness of all persons desiring to practice medicine in this state.
  2. The board is empowered and directed to:
    1. Grant, refuse to grant, suspend, restrict, revoke, reinstate or renew licenses to practice medicine;
    2. Investigate allegations and take disciplinary action on the following grounds:
      1. A licensee is impaired or has engaged in errant conduct;
      2. A person has violated an applicable provision of this chapter or the board’s regulations.
    3. Conduct informal interviews and contested case proceedings;
    4. Adopt a seal;
    5. Adopt, amend, repeal, enforce and promulgate reasonable rules and regulations necessary to implement the provisions of this chapter;
    6. Develop standards governing the delegation of a licensee’s medical responsibilities to nonphysicians;
    7. Publish annually and submit to the governor a report which includes the following information:
      1. A summary of the kind and number of action taken by the board including dates, types and origin of oral or written complaints received and case summaries of physicians whose licenses have been suspended or revoked and any other disciplinary actions;
      2. Board fiscal transactions for the preceding year, the amount of its accumulated cash and securities and a balance sheet showing its financial condition by means of an actuarial valuation of board assets and liabilities.
    8. Publicize information regarding the filing of complaints;
    9. Comply with all applicable federal law;
    10. Verify the status of licenses and privileges held by licensees and applicants for licensure with the federation of state medical boards, medical licensing boards in other jurisdictions and federal data banks, and to provide verification of the status of licenses held in this state by licensees to the entities specified in this paragraph;
    11. Annually review any licensee whose license is restricted or is issued subject to any condition;
    12. Participate in and contract with a program or programs to assist in the return to practice of licensees who have exhibited disruptive behaviors, substance dependence or abuse or are suffering from physical or mental impairment;
    13. Take all reasonable action, including the promulgation of rules and regulations, necessary to enforce this chapter;
    14. Adopt, amend, repeal, enforce and promulgate reasonable rules and regulations necessary to implement and administer continuing medical education requirements of its licensees. The board shall require licensees who are registered with the board of pharmacy to dispense a controlled substance in this state to complete one (1) hour of continuing education related to the responsible prescribing of controlled substances or the treatment of substance abuse disorders every two (2) years.
    15. Publish nonbinding advisory opinions or other guidance on the application and interpretation of this act and the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to this act;
    16. Request criminal history background information for purposes of licensure and discipline, as authorized under W.S. 7-19-106(a);
    17. Use, retain or employ investigators, the offices of the attorney general, the state division of criminal investigation, any other investigatory or fact finding agency and medical specialty consultants, as necessary, to investigate and evaluate complaints against licensees and possible violations of this act and the board’s rules;
    18. Adopt rules and regulations for the practice of medicine in Wyoming by physicians and physician assistants not otherwise licensed in Wyoming in the event of a public health emergency or pandemic;
    19. Adopt rules and regulations for the practice of telemedicine.

History. Laws 1899, ch. 18, § 3; R.S. 1899, § 2194; Laws 1905, ch. 45, § 3; C.S. 1910, § 2867; C.S. 1920, § 3515; R.S. 1931, § 86-103; C.S. 1945, § 37-2003; W.S. 1957, § 33-330; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-104; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, § 1; 1995, ch. 129, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, § 2; 2009, ch. 201, § 1; 2019, ch. 153, § 1.

The 2009 amendment, rewrote (b)(x) which read: “Verify the status of licenses and privileges held by licensees with the federation of state licensing boards and federal data banks, and,” in (b)(xii), substituted “contract with” for “contribute to” and inserted “or abuse,” and added (b)(xv) through (b)(xix).

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, in (b)(xiv), added the last sentence.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-26-102(a)(xxi).

Conduct defined. —

Wyoming Board of Medicine conducted a six-day contested case hearing in front of an independent hearing examiner, both parties participated in pre-hearing motion practice, presented evidence, conducted direct and cross-examination of witnesses, and submitted the case to the Board; this satisfied the statutory requirement that the Board “conduct” the contested case proceeding. Painter v. Hallingbye, 2021 WY 78, 489 P.3d 684, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 86 (Wyo. 2021).

Quoted in

Kirbens v. Wyoming State Bd. of Med., 992 P.2d 1056, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 209 (Wyo. 1999).

§ 33-26-203. Board; employment and salary of executive director; and other employees; compensation of members.

  1. The board may employ or contract with an executive director, board counsel, board prosecutor and other necessary staff. The executive director shall not be a board member.
  2. The executive director’s compensation and terms of employment shall, and board counsel’s and the board prosecutor’s compensation may, be set by the board. The compensation of other staff shall be set by the human resources division of the department of administration and information.
  3. Board members shall receive salary in the same manner and amount as members of the Wyoming legislature and shall receive per diem and mileage as provided in W.S. 33-1-302(a)(vii), incurred in the performance of their official duties. Any incidental expenses necessarily incurred by the board or any member, if approved by the board, shall be paid from the account from fees collected pursuant to this chapter.

History. Laws 1899, ch. 18, § 17; R.S. 1899, § 2206; Laws 1905, ch. 45, § 17; C.S. 1910, § 2881; C.S. 1920, § 3529; R.S. 1931, § 86-117; C.S. 1945, § 37-2017; Laws 1955, ch. 18, § 1; 1957, ch. 152, § 5; W.S. 1957, § 33-332; Laws 1973, ch. 179, § 1; ch. 245, § 3; 1976, ch. 24, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-106; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 29, § 3; 1997, ch. 178, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, § 2; 2005, ch. 231, § 1; 2009, ch. 201, § 1; 2014, ch. 69, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to meal, lodging and traveling expenses of state officers and employees, see § 9-3-102 .

As to amount of mileage fee or mileage expense to state, county or precinct officer or employee, see § 9-3-103 .

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, deleted “within the earmarked revenue fund” following “account” in (c)

The 2009 amendment, in (a), substituted both instances of “executive director” for “executive secretary” and inserted “board prosecutor” in the first sentence; rewrote (b) concerning the executive secretary's salary; and, in (c), rewrote the first sentence which read: “Board members shall not receive compensation for their services but shall receive mileage and per diem in the same manner and amount as members of the Wyoming legislature.”

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

The 2014 amendment, effective July 1, 2014, in (c), substituted “shall receive per diem and mileage as provided in W.S. 33-1-302(a)(vii)” for “shall be reimbursed for actual and necessary expenses and mileage” in the first sentence.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2005, ch. 231, § 3, provides: “The provisions of this act shall supersede the provisions of any other bill enacted into law during the 2005 general session which amends or references accounts or funds to the extent any other enactment is inconsistent with the establishment of the funds and accounts created under this act. The state auditor shall account for any fund or account created in any other legislation enacted in the 2005 general session in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) as promulgated by the governmental accounting standards board (GASB) and in accordance with this act.”

Article 3. Licensing

  • § 33-26-301.  License required.
  • § 33-26-302.  USMLE examination.
  • § 33-26-303.  Requirements for granting license.
  • § 33-26-304.  Temporary license to practice medicine; medical training license; application; qualifications.
  • § 33-26-305.  Annual renewal; expiration; reactivation of lapsed and inactive licenses; restoration of emeritus licenses to active status; duplicates.
  • § 33-26-306.  [Repealed.]
  • § 33-26-307.  Fees.

Required licensure of general nondental anesthesiologists constitutional. —

No offense was dealt the equal protection clause of the United States constitution or the Wyoming state constitution by requiring that general nondental anesthesiologists be properly licensed as physicians under the Wyoming Medical Practice Act, and not just be declared qualified anesthesiologists by an accredited residency program. Paravecchio v. Memorial Hosp., 742 P.2d 1276, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 507 (Wyo. 1987), reh'g denied, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 523 (Wyo. Oct. 7, 1987), overruled in part, Torres v. State ex rel. Wyo. Workers' Safety & Comp. Div., 2004 WY 92, 95 P.3d 794, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 2004).

§ 33-26-301. License required.

  1. No person shall practice medicine in this state without a license granted by the board, or as otherwise provided by law.
  2. Upon appropriate application, fulfillment of eligibility criteria and successful completion of all other requirements, the board may grant:
    1. A license to practice medicine, subject to annual renewal;
    2. A temporary license to practice medicine pursuant to W.S. 33-26-304(a);
    3. A restricted or conditional license;
    4. An inactive license, provided the qualifications for and the conditions of this license shall be established by rule;
    5. A medical training license pursuant to W.S. 33-26-304(c);
    6. An emeritus license, allowing retired physicians to provide health care without remuneration, provided the qualifications for and the conditions of this license shall be established by rule;
    7. A volunteer license, allowing physicians not otherwise licensed in Wyoming to practice medicine in the state without remuneration, provided the qualifications for and conditions of this license shall be established by rule;
    8. An administrative medicine license for physicians not providing patient care, provided the qualifications for and the conditions of this license shall be established by rule.

History. Laws 1899, ch. 18, §§ 4, 5; R.S. 1899, § 2163; Laws 1905, ch. 45, § 4; C.S. 1910, § 2868; Laws 1917, ch. 111, § 2; C.S. 1920, § 3516; Laws 1925, ch. 126, § 1; R.S. 1931, § 86-104; C.S. 1945, § 37-2004; Laws 1957, ch. 194, § 2; W.S. 1957, § 33-333; Laws 1963, ch. 177, § 1; 1965, ch. 176, § 1; 1969, ch. 114, § 1; 1973, ch. 223, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-112; Laws 1981, ch. 78, § 1; 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1995, ch. 129, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, § 2; 2006, ch. 58, § 1; 2009, ch. 201, § 1.

The 2006 amendment, effective July 1, 2006, in (b), deleted “permanent” preceding “license” in (i); substituted “33-26-304(a)” for “33-26-304” in (ii); added (v), and made a related change.

The 2009 amendment, added “or as otherwise provided by law” at the end of (a); added (b)(vi) through (b)(viii); and made related changes.

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Tort claim for negligent credentialing of physician, 98 ALR5th 533.

§ 33-26-302. USMLE examination.

  1. The board shall adopt regulations for the qualification for and administration of the USMLE.
  2. through (f) Repealed by Laws 2003, ch. 190, § 3.

History. Laws 1899, ch. 18, §§ 4, 5; R.S. 1899, § 2163; Laws 1905, ch. 45, §§ 4, 5; C.S. 1910, §§ 2868, 2869; Laws 1917, ch. 111, § 2; C.S. 1920, §§ 3516, 3517; Laws 1925, ch. 126, § 1; 1929, ch. 96, § 1; 1931, ch. 86, § 1; R.S. 1931, §§ 86-104, 86-105; C.S. 1945, §§ 37-2004, 37-2005; Laws 1957, ch. 194, § 2; ch. 142, § 6; W.S. 1957, §§ 33-333, 33-335; Laws 1963, ch. 177, § 1; 1965, ch. 176, §§ 1, 2; 1969, ch. 114, § 1; 1973, ch. 223, § 1; 1976; ch. 24, § 2; W.S. 1977, §§ 33-26-112, 33-26-114; Laws 1981, ch. 78, § 1; 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, § 1; 1995, ch. 129, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, §§ 2, 3.

§ 33-26-303. Requirements for granting license.

  1. The board may grant a license to practice medicine in this state as provided in the Interstate Medical Licensure Compact or, under this article, to any applicant who demonstrates, to the board, that he:
    1. Repealed by Laws 2003, ch. 190, § 3.
    2. Has graduated from a school of medicine accredited by the L.C.M.E., a school of osteopathy accredited by the A.O.A., a Canadian accredited school of medicine or has been certified by the E.C.F.M.G.;
    3. Repealed by Laws 2003, ch. 190, § 3.
    4. Has provided written evidence that he has completed at least one (1) year of postgraduate training in an A.C.G.M.E, A.O.A. or R.C.P.S.C. accredited program;
    5. Has presented other credentials and qualifications equivalent to or exceeding the criteria in paragraph (iv) of this subsection as may be considered by the board to demonstrate competency to practice medicine in this state;
    6. Has successfully completed all three (3) parts of the USMLE, national boards, the FLEX, a board approved, state constructed licensing examination, the examination by the licentiate of the medical council of Canada or the COMLEX, provided the conditions and requirements for completion of all parts of the examinations shall be established by board rule;
    7. Has completed an application form provided or approved by the board;
    8. Has paid the appropriate fees pursuant to W.S. 33-26-307 ;
    9. Has completed to the satisfaction of a majority of board members, if required pursuant to board rule, a personal interview consisting of inquiry and oral response to medical knowledge, personal and professional history and intentions for practicing medicine in this state; and
    10. Repealed by Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 2.
    11. Meets any additional requirements that the board may impose by regulation which are necessary to implement this act.
  2. A person who has pled guilty to or has been convicted of a felony or any crime that is a felony under Wyoming law in any state or federal court or in any court of similar jurisdiction in another country may apply for licensure provided, the board may deny licensure based upon the plea or conviction alone.
  3. A person whose medical license has been revoked, suspended, restricted, had conditions placed on it or been voluntarily or involuntarily relinquished or surrendered, by or to another state medical or licensing board, or has a disciplinary action pending before another state medical or licensing board, may apply for licensure provided, however, the board may deny licensure based upon the revocation, suspension, restrictions, conditions, relinquishment, surrender of licensure or pending disciplinary action alone.
  4. A person whose clinical privileges at a health care facility have been revoked, suspended, restricted, had conditions placed upon them or been voluntarily or involuntarily resigned, or against whom a clinical privilege action is pending at a health care facility, may apply for licensure provided, however, the board may deny licensure based upon the revocation, suspension, restrictions, conditions, resignation of privileges or pending clinical privilege action alone.

History. Laws 1899, ch. 18, §§ 4, 5; R.S. 1899, § 2163; Laws 1905, ch. 45, § 4; C.S. 1910, § 2868; Laws 1917, ch. 111, § 2; C.S. 1920, § 3516; Laws 1925, ch. 126, § 1; R.S. 1931, § 86-104; C.S. 1945, § 37-2004; Laws 1957, ch. 194, § 2; W.S. 1957, § 33-333; Laws 1963, ch. 177, § 1; 1965, ch. 176, § 1; 1969, ch. 114, § 1; 1973, ch. 223, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-112; Laws 1981, ch. 78, § 1; 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, § 1; 1995, ch. 129, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, §§ 2, 3; 2005, ch. 223, § 1; 2009, ch. 201, §§ 1, 2; 2015, ch. 62, § 2.

The 2005 amendment, in (a)(iv), lowered the minimum requirement of postgraduate training from three years to two years.

Laws 2005, ch. 223, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2005.

The 2009 amendment, substituted “to the board” for “to the satisfaction of a majority of the board” in the introductory language of (a); added “or has been certified by the E.C.F.M.G.” at the end of (a)(ii); deleted the former last sentence in (a)(iv) which read “An applicant who graduated from a medical school not accredited by the L.C.M.E. or A.O.A. shall present written evidence that he has completed at least two (2) years of medical education at the medical school from which he graduated and that he has completed at least two (2) years of postgraduate training in an A.C.G.M.E., A.O.A. or R.C.P.S.C. accredited program”; substituted “or the COMLEX, provided the conditions and requirements for completion of all parts of the examinations shall be established by board rule” for “the examination developed by the national board of osteopathic medical examiners” in (a)(vi); inserted “or approved” in (a)(vii); inserted “if required pursuant to board rule” in (a)(ix); repealed former (a)(x) pertaining to license suspension, revocation or restrictions; added (c) and (d); and made related changes.

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

The 2015 amendment, effective July 1, 2015, in the introductory language of (a), inserted “as provided in the Interstate Medical Licensure Compact or, under this article” and made a related change.

Meaning of “this act.” —

The term “this act,” referred to in subsection (a)(xi), apparently means this chapter, i.e., §§ 33-26-101 through 33-26-601 .

§ 33-26-304. Temporary license to practice medicine; medical training license; application; qualifications.

  1. The board may issue a temporary license for a term that expires at 8:00 a.m. on the first day of the next regularly scheduled board meeting to a person who:
    1. Completes an application as approved by the board for temporary licensure;
    2. Meets all licensing requirements of W.S. 33-26-303 except that the board may defer the interview required by W.S. 33-26-303 (a)(ix) at its discretion until no later than the next board meeting;
    3. Pays a temporary license fee in an amount set by the board.
  2. The board, in its discretion may extend a temporary license for an additional term no longer than 8:00 a.m. on the first day of the second regularly scheduled board meeting following the date of the initial issuance of a temporary license.
  3. The board may issue a medical training license for a term that expires at 12:01 a.m. July 1 of each year to a person who:
    1. Has signed a contract with an A.C.G.M.E. accredited residency program located in this state;
    2. Has graduated from a school of medicine accredited by the L.C.M.E., a school of osteopathy accredited by the A.O.A. or a Canadian accredited school of medicine, or has been certified by the E.C.F.M.G.;
    3. Has successfully completed steps one (1) and two (2) of the USMLE or the COMLEX;
    4. Is under the supervision of residency faculty;
    5. Has completed an application form provided by the board;
    6. Has paid the appropriate fees pursuant to W.S. 33-26-307 ; and
    7. Repealed by Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 2.
    8. Meets any additional requirements that the board may impose by regulation which are necessary to implement this act.
  4. A person who has pled guilty to or has been convicted of a felony or any crime that is a felony under Wyoming law in any state or federal court or in any court of similar jurisdiction in another country may apply for licensure, provided the board may deny licensure based upon the plea or conviction alone.
  5. A person whose medical license has been revoked, suspended, restricted, had conditions placed on it or been voluntarily or involuntarily relinquished or surrendered, by or to another state medical or licensing board, or has a disciplinary action pending before another state medical or licensing board, may apply for licensure provided, however, the board may deny licensure based upon the revocation, suspension, restrictions, conditions, relinquishment, surrender of licensure or pending disciplinary action alone.
  6. A person whose clinical privileges at a health care facility have been revoked, suspended, restricted, had conditions placed upon them or been voluntarily or involuntarily resigned, or against whom a clinical privilege action is pending at a health care facility, may apply for licensure provided, however, the board may deny licensure based upon the revocation, suspension, restrictions, conditions, resignation of privileges or pending clinical privilege action alone.

History. Laws 1961, ch. 16, §§ 1, 2; W.S. 1957, §§ 33-332.1, 33-332.2; W.S. 1977, §§ 33-26-107, 33-26-108; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, § 2; 2006, ch. 58, § 1; 2009, ch. 201, §§ 1, 2.

The 2006 amendment, effective July 1, 2006, added (c) and (d).

The 2009 amendment, substituted “expires at 8:00 a.m. on the first day “ for “expires on the date” in the introductory language of (a); inserted “no later than” in (a)(ii); rewrote (b) which read: “A temporary license is valid until the date of the next board meeting following the date of issuance. The board, in its discretion may extend a temporary license for an additional term no longer than the date of the second regular board meeting following the date of issuance.”; added “or has been certified by the E.C.F.M.G.” at the end of (c)(ii); added “or the COMLEX” at the end of (c)(iii); repealed former (c)(vii) pertaining to pertaining to license suspension, revocation or restrictions; added (e) and (f); and made a stylistic change.

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

Meaning of “this act.” —

The term “this act” referred to in subsection (c)(viii), apparently means this Article, i.e., §§ 33-26-301 through 33-26-307 .

§ 33-26-305. Annual renewal; expiration; reactivation of lapsed and inactive licenses; restoration of emeritus licenses to active status; duplicates.

  1. All licenses other than temporary licenses and medical training licenses shall lapse annually on a date or dates to be established by rules adopted by the board. A licensee may renew his license each year by submitting a renewal application containing information required by the board, accompanied by proof of compliance with and fulfillment of continuing medical education requirements of the board in the manner set forth in the board’s continuing medical education rules and regulations and a renewal fee to the board in an amount set by the board pursuant to W.S. 33-26-307 . The licensee additionally shall report any disciplinary action pending or taken by a state examining board, a health care entity or the grievance committee of a medical society during the preceding year.
  2. Repealed by Laws 2003, ch. 190, § 3.
  3. The board may reactivate a lapsed or inactive license if the applicant meets the requirements established by the rules and regulations promulgated by the board.
  4. A licensee shall apply to the board for a duplicate license if his license is stolen, lost or destroyed. Upon proof of proper identification, the required fee and submission of other information as the board may require, the board shall issue a duplicate license bearing on its face the word “DUPLICATE”.
  5. The board may restore an emeritus license to active status if the applicant meets the requirements established by the rules and regulations promulgated by the board.

History. Laws 1905, ch. 45, § 5; C.S. 1910, § 2869; C.S. 1920, § 3517; Laws 1929, ch. 96, § 1; 1931, ch. 86, § 1; R.S. 1931, § 86-105; C.S. 1945, § 37-2005; Laws 1957, ch. 142, § 6; W.S. 1957, § 33-335; Laws 1965, ch. 176, § 2; 1973, ch. 223, § 1; 1976, ch. 24, § 2; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-114; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, §§ 2, 3; 2006, ch. 58, § 1; 2009, ch. 201, § 1.

The 2006 amendment, effective July 1, 2006, rewrote (a), changing the annual medical training licenses renewal date, renewal application process, and renewal fee; and made a stylistic change in (c).

The 2009 amendment, rewrote (c) which read: “The board may reactivate a lapsed license if the applicant pays a reactivation fee and fulfills all requirements for the granting of an initial license.”; and added (e).

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

§ 33-26-306. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1995, ch. 129, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1905, ch. 45, § 6, related to the issuance of a license by endorsement.

§ 33-26-307. Fees.

  1. The board shall set by regulation appropriate license application, renewal and reactivation fees, examination fees and fees for information verification or document production and other services of the board to be charged under this chapter.
    1. through (vii) Repealed by Laws 2003, ch. 190, § 3.
  2. All money received or collected under this chapter shall be paid to the state treasurer for deposit in a separate account. The money in the account is subject at all times to the warrant of the state auditor drawn upon written requisition attested by the executive director of the board for the payment of any board expenses.

History. Laws 1899, ch. 18, § 11; R.S. 1899, § 2205; Laws 1905, ch. 45, §§ 5, 11; C.S. 1910, §§ 2869, 2875; C.S. 1920, §§ 3517, 3523; Laws 1929, ch. 96, § 1; 1931, ch. 86, § 1; R.S. 1931, §§ 86-105, 86-111; C.S. 1945, §§ 37-2005, 37-2011; Laws 1957, ch. 142, § 6; ch. 248, § 1; W.S. 1957, §§ 33-331, 33-332.5, 33-335; Laws 1961, ch. 16, § 5; 1965, ch. 176, § 2; 1973, ch. 223, § 1; ch. 245, § 3; 1976, ch. 24, § 2; W.S. 1977, §§ 33-26-105, 33-26-111, 33-26-114; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, § 1; 1995, ch. 129, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, §§ 2, 3; 2005, ch. 231, § 1; 2009, ch. 201, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, in (b) substituted “a separate account” for “an account within the earmarked revenue fund” and made a related change.

The 2009 amendment, substituted “written requisition attested by the executive director of the board” for “written requisition of the president and attested by the executive secretary of the board, with seal attached,” in the last sentence of (b).

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2005, ch. 231, § 3, provides: “The provisions of this act shall supersede the provisions of any other bill enacted into law during the 2005 general session which amends or references accounts or funds to the extent any other enactment is inconsistent with the establishment of the funds and accounts created under this act. The state auditor shall account for any fund or account created in any other legislation enacted in the 2005 general session in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) as promulgated by the governmental accounting standards board (GASB) and in accordance with this act.”

Article 4. Investigations and Disciplinary Proceedings

  • § 33-26-401.  Board duties; investigation; interview.
  • § 33-26-402.  Grounds for suspension; revocation; restriction; imposition of conditions; refusal to renew or other disciplinary action.
  • § 33-26-403.  Impaired physicians.
  • § 33-26-404.  Voluntary and mandatory revocation; restriction; suspension.
  • § 33-26-405.  Order of the board.
  • § 33-26-406.  Reinstatement of license; removal of restrictions or conditions from a license.
  • § 33-26-407.  Judicial review.
  • § 33-26-408.  Protected action and communication.
  • § 33-26-409.  Health care entity reports required; malpractice.
  • § 33-26-410.  Effect of violation.

§ 33-26-401. Board duties; investigation; interview.

  1. The board shall investigate, upon a written and signed complaint or by its own motion, any information that if proven would fall within the jurisdiction of the board and would constitute a violation of this act.
  2. Before holding a contested case hearing, the board shall conduct an informal interview with the licensee unless the licensee waives an interview.
  3. Notwithstanding any other provision of law the board may require, by administrative subpoena, the testimony of licensees and witnesses and the production of evidence relating to any matter under investigation.
  4. All evidence admitted into the record of any contested case hearing held before the board shall be subject to the confidentiality provisions set forth in W.S. 33-26-408 unless waived by the licensee.
  5. The board retains jurisdiction over only those licensees to whom temporary or full licenses were granted and who are subject to ongoing investigation by the board, regardless of whether the license expired, lapsed or was relinquished during or after the alleged occurrence of conduct proscribed by W.S. 33-26-402 by the licensee.

History. Laws 1976, ch. 24, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 33-340.4; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-130; Laws 1981, ch. 78, § 1; 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, § 2.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of this act, referred to in this section, see § 33-26-102(a)(xxi).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Mandamus to compel disciplinary investigation or action against physician or attorney, 33 ALR3d 1429.

Rights as to notice and hearing in proceeding to revoke or suspend license to practice medicine, 10 ALR5th 1.

§ 33-26-402. Grounds for suspension; revocation; restriction; imposition of conditions; refusal to renew or other disciplinary action.

  1. The board may refuse to renew, and may revoke, suspend or restrict a license or take other disciplinary action, including the imposition of conditions or restrictions upon a license on one (1) or more of the following grounds:
    1. Renewing, obtaining or attempting to obtain or renew a license by bribery, fraud or misrepresentation;
    2. Impersonating another licensee or practicing medicine under a false or assumed name;
    3. Making false or misleading statements regarding the licensee’s skill or the efficacy or value of his treatment or remedy for a human disease, injury, deformity, ailment, pregnancy or delivery of infants;
    4. Permitting or allowing any person to use his diploma, license or certificate of registration;
    5. Advertising the practice of medicine in a misleading, false or deceptive manner;
    6. Obtaining any fee or claim for payment of a fee by fraud or misrepresentation;
    7. Repealed by Laws 2018, ch. 80, §  3.
    8. Conviction of or pleading guilty or nolo contendere to a felony or any crime that is a felony under Wyoming law in any jurisdiction;
    9. Aiding or abetting the practice of medicine by a person not licensed by the board;
    10. Violating or attempting to violate or assist in the violation of any provision of this chapter or any other applicable provision of law;
    11. Except as permitted by law, repeatedly prescribing or administering, selling or supplying any drug legally classified as a narcotic, addicting or scheduled drug to a known abuser;
    12. Repeatedly prescribing, selling, supplying or administering any drug legally classified as a narcotic, addicting or scheduled drug to a parent, spouse or child of the applicant or licensee, or to himself;
    13. Presigning blank prescription forms;
    14. Failing or refusing to properly guard against the spread of contagious, infectious or communicable diseases;
    15. Failure to appropriately supervise nonphysicians to whom the licensee has delegated medical responsibilities;
    16. Delegating responsibilities to a person who is not qualified by training, experience or licensure;
    17. Delegating medical responsibilities to a person who is unable to safely, skillfully and competently provide medical care to patients or that are beyond the scope of the specialty areas in which the licensee and the person are trained and experienced;
    18. Willful and consistent utilization of medical service or treatment which is inappropriate or unnecessary;
    19. A manifest incapacity to practice medicine with reasonable skill and safety to patients;
    20. Possession of any physical or mental disability including deterioration due to aging which renders the practice of medicine unsafe;
    21. Use of a drug or intoxicant to such a degree as to render the licensee unable to practice medicine or surgery with reasonable skill and safety to patients;
    22. Practicing medicine below the applicable standard of care, regardless of causation or damage;
    23. Failure to submit to an informal interview or a mental, physical or medical competency examination following a proper request by the board pursuant to W.S. 33-26-403 ;
    24. Failure to report a personal injury claim as required by W.S. 33-26-409 ;
    25. Suspension, probation, imposition of conditions or restrictions, relinquishment, surrender or revocation of a license to practice medicine in another jurisdiction;
    26. Any action by a health care entity that:
      1. Adversely affects clinical privileges for a period of thirty (30) or more consecutive days;
      2. Results in the surrender of clinical privileges to the health care entity while the licensee is under investigation by the health care entity for possible professional incompetence or improper professional conduct; or
      3. Results in the surrender of clinical privileges in return for the health care entity not conducting an investigation for possible professional incompetence or improper professional conduct.
    27. Unprofessional or dishonorable conduct not otherwise specified in this subsection, including but not limited to:
      1. Repealed by Laws 2003, ch. 190, § 3.
      2. Failure to conform to the applicable standard of care;
      3. Willful or careless disregard for the health, welfare or safety of a patient;
      4. Engaging in any conduct or practice that is harmful or dangerous to the health of a patient or the public;
      5. Engaging in conduct intended to or likely to deceive, defraud or harm the public;
      6. Using any false, fraudulent or deceptive statement in any document connected with the practice of medicine including the intentional falsification or fraudulent alteration of a patient or health care facility record;
      7. Failing to prepare and maintain legible and complete written medical records that accurately describe the medical services rendered to the patient, including the patient’s history, pertinent findings, examination, results, test results and all treatment provided;
      8. Practicing outside of the scope of the licensee’s expertise and training;
      9. Repeatedly engaging in harassing, disruptive or abusive behavior directed at staff, co-workers, a patient or a patient’s relative or guardian or that interferes with the provision of patient care;
      10. Engaging in conduct that relates adversely to the practice of medicine or to the ability to practice medicine, including but not limited to conviction of or pleading guilty or nolo contendere to domestic abuse, stalking, sexual assault, sexual abuse or unlawful exploitation of a minor, indecent exposure, incest or distribution of pornography;
      11. Failing or neglecting to attempt to inform a patient within a reasonable time of the results of a laboratory test indicating the need for further clinical review;
      12. Improperly terminating a physician-patient relationship;
      13. Representing that a manifestly incurable disease or condition can be permanently cured or that any disease or condition can be cured by a secret method, procedure, treatment, medicine or device if the representation is untrue;
      14. Intentionally or negligently releasing or disclosing confidential patient information. This restriction shall not apply to disclosures permitted or required by state or federal law or when disclosure is necessary to prevent imminent risk of harm to the patient or others;
      15. Failing or refusing to transfer a copy of patient records to the patient or the patient’s legally designated representative within thirty (30) days after receipt of a written request;
      16. Utilization of experimental forms of therapy without proper informed consent from the patient, without conforming to generally-accepted criteria or standard protocols, without keeping detailed, legible records or without having periodic analysis of the study and results reviewed by a committee of peers;
      17. Except in emergency situations where the consent of the patient or the patient’s legally designated representative cannot be reasonably obtained, assisting in the care or treatment of a patient without the consent of the patient, the attending physician or the patient’s legal representative;
      18. Using or engaging in fraud or deceit to obtain third party reimbursement.
    28. Upon proper request by the board, failure or refusal to produce documents or other information relevant to any investigation conducted by the board, whether the complaint is filed against the licensee or any other licensee;
    29. and (xxx) Repealed by Laws 2003, ch. 190, § 3.
    30. Violation of any board rule or regulation;
    31. Acquiring or attempting or conspiring to acquire any drug classified as a narcotic, addicting or scheduled drug by fraud or deception;
    32. Initially prescribing any controlled substance specified in W.S. 35-7-1016 through 35-7-1022 for any person through the Internet, the World Wide Web or a similar proprietary or common carrier electronic system absent a documented physician-patient relationship;
    33. Violating any final order, consent decree or stipulation between the board and the licensee;
    34. Any behavior by a licensee toward a patient, former patient, another licensee, an employee of a health care facility, an employee of the licensee or a relative or guardian of a patient that exploits the position of trust, knowledge, emotions or influence of the licensee.
  2. Upon a finding of ineligibility for licensure or refusal to grant a license under subsection (a) of this section, the board shall file its written order and findings.

History. Laws 1976, ch. 24, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 33-340.3; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-129; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, § 1; 1995, ch. 129, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, §§ 2, 3; 2009, ch. 201, § 1; 2018, ch. 80, §§ 2, 3; ch. 107, § 2.

The 2009 amendment, inserted “relinquishment, surrender” in (a)(xxv); substituted “period of thirty (30) or more consecutive days” for “period exceeding thirty (30) days” at the end of (a)(xxvi)(A); and substituted “disclosures permitted or required” for “disclosures required” in (a)(xxvii)(P).

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

The 2018 amendments. — The first 2018 amendment, by ch. 80, § 2, effective July 1, 2018, added (a)(xxxv); and made a related stylistic change.

The second 2018 amendment, by ch. 80, § 3, effective July 1, 2018, repealed former (a)(vii), which read: “Sexual misconduct.”

The third 2018 amendment, by ch. 107, § 2, effective July 1, 2018, in (a)(xxvii)(K), substituted “relates adversely to the practice of medicine or to the ability to practice medicine” for “constitutes moral turpitude” following “conduct that.”

While neither amendment gave effect to the others, all have been given effect in this section as set out above.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subparagraph (a)(xxvii)(I) or (L) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Recovery for malpractice. —

To recover for malpractice, a plaintiff must show that the physician or surgeon was unskillful or negligent, and that his lack of skill or care caused injury to the plaintiff. Rosson v. Hylton, 45 Wyo. 540, 22 P.2d 195, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1933).

Expert testimony not required. —

Nature of the violation and the facts underlying it are within the Wyoming Board of Medicine and the court’s knowledge, and thus petitioner was not required to present expert testimony to prove the doctor exploited her professional relationship with the patient. Painter v. Hallingbye, 2021 WY 78, 489 P.3d 684, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 86 (Wyo. 2021).

Exploit defined. —

Wyoming Medical Practice Act prohibits any behavior toward a patient that exploits the position of trust, knowledge, emotions or influence of the licensee; the court adopts the ordinary definition of the verb exploit: to make use of meanly or unfairly for one’s own advantage. Painter v. Hallingbye, 2021 WY 78, 489 P.3d 684, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 86 (Wyo. 2021).

Violation of this section shown. —

There was clear and convincing evidence that the physician's conduct exhibited willful and consistent utilization of medical services that were inappropriate and unnecessary, in violation of this section. Kirbens v. Wyoming State Bd. of Med., 992 P.2d 1056, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 209 (Wyo. 1999).

Findings of fact made by the Wyoming Board of Medicine supported its conclusion that the doctor exploited her professional relationship with the patient under the plain meaning of the term; but for the doctor’s licensure as a physician, she would not have had access to the patient, nor would she have been able to command the trust and reliance that allowed her to exert control over the patient, her finances, and her ranch. Painter v. Hallingbye, 2021 WY 78, 489 P.3d 684, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 86 (Wyo. 2021).

Wyoming Board of Medicine properly concluded that the doctor violated the statute, as she did not follow the steps required by to terminate the physician-patient relationship, and expert testimony was not required to determine whether the doctor adequately notified her patient of the termination. Painter v. Hallingbye, 2021 WY 78, 489 P.3d 684, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 86 (Wyo. 2021).

Quoted in

Painter v. Abels, 998 P.2d 931, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 42 (Wyo. 2000).

Cited in

Garrison v. Board of Trustees, 795 P.2d 190, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 81 , 28 A.L.R.5th 801 (Wyo. 1990); Devous v. Wyoming State Bd. of Medical Exmrs., 845 P.2d 408, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1993); In re Licensure of Jerry Penny v. State Ex Rel. Wyoming Mental Health Professions Licensing Bd., 2005 WY 117, 120 P.3d 152, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 142 (2005).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity of statute or rule making specified conduct or condition the ground for cancelation or suspension irrespective of licensee's personal fault, 3 ALR2d 107.

Statute authorizing revocation of license upon conviction as applicable to conviction based on plea of nolo contendere or non vult, 89 ALR2d 540.

Alcoholism, narcotics addiction or misconduct with respect to alcohol or narcotics as ground for revocation or suspension of license to practice medicine, 93 ALR2d 1398.

Revocation or suspension of physician's or surgeon's license for false claims, medical reports or bills for medical services in connection with personal injury litigation, 95 ALR2d 873.

Improper or immoral conduct toward female patient as ground for disciplinary measure against physician or dentist, 15 ALR3d 1179.

Professional incompetency as ground for disciplinary measure against physician or dentist, 28 ALR3d 487.

Criminal prosecution or disciplinary action against medical practitioner for fraud in connection with claims for services provided under medicaid, medicare or similar welfare program, 50 ALR3d 549.

Wrongful or excessive prescription of drugs as ground for revocation or suspension of physician's or dentist's license to practice, 22 ALR4th 668.

Imposition of civil penalties, under state statute, upon medical practitioner for fraud in connection with claims under medicaid, medicare, or similar welfare programs for providing medical services, 32 ALR4th 671.

Physician's or other healer's conduct, or conviction of offense, not directly related to medical practice, as ground for disciplinary action, 34 ALR4th 609.

Recovery for emotional distress resulting from statement of medical practitioner or official, allegedly constituting outrageous conduct, 34 ALR4th 688.

Medical malpractice: liability based on misrepresentation of the nature and hazards of treatment, 42 ALR4th 543.

Physician's liability to third person for prescribing drug to known drug addict, 42 ALR4th 586.

Physician's or other healer's conduct in connection with defense of or resistance of malpractice action as ground for revocation of license or other disciplinary action, 44 ALR4th 248.

Filing of false insurance claims for medical services as ground for disciplinary action against dentist, physician or other medical practitioner, 70 ALR4th 132.

Liability for incorrectly diagnosing existence or nature of pregnancy, 2 ALR5th 769.

Liability of hospital, physician, or other medical personnel for death or injury to child caused by improper postdelivery diagnosis, care, and representations, 2 ALR5th 811.

False or fraudulent statements or nondisclosures in application for issuance or renewal of license to practice as ground for disciplinary action against, or refusal to license, medical practitioner, 32 ALR5th 57.

Physical injury requirement for emotional distress claim based on false positive conclusion on medical test diagnosing disease, 69 ALR5th 411.

Wrongful or excessive prescription of drugs as ground for revocation or suspension of physician's or dentist's license to practice. 19 A.L.R.6th 577.

§ 33-26-403. Impaired physicians.

  1. The board may order a licensee to undergo one (1) or more mental, physical or medical competency examinations by examiners deemed appropriate by the board if it has reasonable cause to believe that the licensee may be impaired. If a disciplinary proceeding is pending against the licensee at the time of the order, the proceeding shall be stayed until the results of the examination have been finalized and submitted to the board.
  2. Every licensee is deemed to have consented to and shall submit to a board ordered mental, physical, or medical competency examination and to have waived all objections to the production of the report of the examination to the board and the admissibility of the report of the examination in any board proceedings in which the licensee is or may become a respondent. If a licensee fails to submit to an examination when ordered by the board, the board may initiate a disciplinary proceeding against the licensee or amend a pending complaint to include a claim based upon a violation of this section.
  3. Repealed by Laws 2006, ch. 58, § 2.
  4. The licensee may submit additional information to the board, including but not limited to medical reports, consultations or laboratory reports obtained through an examination performed by a practitioner designated by the licensee.
  5. The results of any board ordered mental, physical competency or medical competency examination shall be provided to the licensee and the board prior to any further board action.

History. Laws 1976, ch. 24, § 1; W.S. 1957, §§ 33-340.5, 33-340.6, 33-340.8; W.S. 1977, §§ 33-26-131, 33-26-132, 33-26-134; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, § 2; 2006, ch. 58, §§ 1, 2.

The 2006 amendment, effective July 1, 2006, in (a), in the first sentence, deleted “competency” following “physical,” inserted “by examiners deemed appropriate by the board,” substituted “If a disciplinary proceeding is pending against the licensee at the time of the order, the proceeding” for “Any disciplinary proceeding pending against the licensee at the time of the order, the proceeding” in the second sentence; in (b), substituted “ordered” for “requested” in two places, inserted “or may become,” inserted “or amend a pending complaint to include a claim”; repealed former (c) which pertained to reasonable cause by the board to conduct competency examination of licensee; substituted “obtained through an examination performed by a practitioner designated by the licensee” for “The licensee may also designate another physician to be present at the examination and make an independent report to the board” in (d); and made related changes.

Due process. —

The board's failure to provide the physician notice of the right to designate an independent physician, coupled with the short time frame between delivery of the notice and date of the examination, effectively precluded her from exercising the right to provide independent analysis. Painter v. Abels, 998 P.2d 931, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 42 (Wyo. 2000).

§ 33-26-404. Voluntary and mandatory revocation; restriction; suspension.

  1. A licensee may request the board, in writing, to accept the voluntary relinquishment, restriction or suspension of his license. The board may, but shall not be required to accept the relinquished license, grant the request for restriction or suspension, attach conditions to the license or waive the commencement of any proceedings under this article. Removal of a voluntary relinquishment, restriction or suspension is subject to the procedure for reinstatement of a license as provided in this article.
  2. Unless the board and the licensee have agreed to the relinquishment of or imposition of restrictions or conditions on a license, the board shall conduct a proceeding to refuse to renew or reinstate, revoke, restrict or suspend a license on the grounds set forth in W.S. 33-26-402(a) as a contested case under the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act.
  3. The board may temporarily suspend the license of any licensee without a hearing pursuant to W.S. 16-3-113(c).
  4. Upon receipt from the department of family services of a certified copy of an order from a court to withhold, suspend or otherwise restrict a license issued by the board, the board shall notify the party named in the court order of the withholding, suspension or restriction of the license in accordance with the terms of the court order. No appeal under the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act shall be allowed for a license withheld, suspended or restricted under this subsection.

History. Laws 1976, ch. 24, § 1; W.S. 1957, §§ 33-340.7, 33-340.9; W.S. 1977, §§ 33-26-133, 33-26-135; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, § 1; 1997, ch. 128, § 2; 2003, ch. 190, § 2.

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

See § 16-3-101(a), (b)(xi).

Conduct defined. —

Wyoming Board of Medicine conducted a six-day contested case hearing in front of an independent hearing examiner, both parties participated in pre-hearing motion practice, presented evidence, conducted direct and cross-examination of witnesses, and submitted the case to the Board; this satisfied the statutory requirement that the Board “conduct” the contested case proceeding. Painter v. Hallingbye, 2021 WY 78, 489 P.3d 684, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 86 (Wyo. 2021).

Board not required to accept voluntary relinquishment of license. —

The Wyoming board of medicine was not required to accept the voluntary relinquishment of the physician's license where the physician was the subject of a pending disciplinary proceeding. Kirbens v. Wyoming State Bd. of Med., 992 P.2d 1056, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 209 (Wyo. 1999).

§ 33-26-405. Order of the board.

  1. Following a hearing to refuse to renew or reinstate, revoke, restrict or suspend a license on the grounds set forth in W.S. 33-26-402(a), the board shall enter its order and findings pursuant to the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. The board may take one (1) or more of the following actions:
    1. Dismiss the proceedings;
    2. Issue a public or private reprimand;
    3. Order probation and provide terms;
    4. Impose a civil fine not exceeding twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00);
    5. Suspend the license;
    6. Revoke the license;
    7. Place restrictions on the license;
    8. Assess part or all of the cost of the proceeding against a disciplined licensee;
    9. Take other action as the board in its discretion finds proper;
    10. Place the licensee on probation.
  2. Restriction of a license may include, but is not limited to, the following:
    1. Restricting the practice to certain areas of medicine or forbidding the practice of certain areas of medicine;
    2. Requiring the licensee to practice medicine under the supervision of another physician in a clinic or other controlled setting, and setting the conditions of the licensee’s practice of medicine;
    3. Forbidding the use of certain medical procedures without consultation with and approval by another physician.

History. Laws 1976, ch. 24, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 33-340.10; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-136; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1995, ch. 129, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, § 2; 2009, ch. 201, § 1.

The 2009 amendment, added “, and setting the conditions of the licensee's practice of medicine” at the end of (b)(ii).

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

See § 16-3-101(a), (b)(xi) and notes thereto.

Hearsay admissible. —

Hearsay that is otherwise admissible under § 16-3-108(a), and that is probative, trustworthy and credible may be received in evidence at an agency hearing. Story v. Wyoming State Bd. of Medical Examiners, 721 P.2d 1013, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 573 (Wyo. 1986).

Licensee denied fair and impartial hearing. —

The submission to the board by the state medical society of an unsworn report of the medical society's grievance committee, which report was replete with hearsay, speculation and conjecture, and contained damaging information extraneous to the matters to be heard, resulted in the denial to the licensee of the fair and impartial hearing to which he was entitled. Fallon v. Wyoming State Bd. of Medical Examiners, 441 P.2d 322, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 175 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 443 P.2d 135, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 177 (Wyo. 1968).

Hearing examiner costs like attorney fees. —

Because the expenses of the hearing examiner are to be treated like attorney fees, they were properly not imposed against a vindicated licensee. Devous v. Wyoming State Bd. of Medical Examiners, 845 P.2d 408, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1993).

Prosecuting attorney and officer fees may not be assessed. —

Without statutory authority to the contrary, the Wyoming Board of Medicine is bound by case law and may not assess its prosecuting attorney and Office of Administrative Hearings officer fees against the doctor. Painter v. Hallingbye, 2021 WY 78, 489 P.3d 684, 2021 Wyo. LEXIS 86 (Wyo. 2021).

Cost of proceeding. —

Subdivision (a)(viii), allowing assessment of “part or all of the cost of the proceeding against a disciplined licensee,” does not include the costs and expenses of the hearing officer. Painter v. Abels, 998 P.2d 931, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 42 (Wyo. 2000).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Determination by board on its own knowledge, without expert evidence, in proceeding for revocation of license, 6 ALR2d 675.

Statute of limitations or doctrine of laches as applicable to proceeding to revoke license to practice medicine, 63 ALR2d 1080.

Disqualification, for bias or interest, of member of occupation or profession sitting in license revocation proceeding, 97 ALR2d 1210.

Pretrial discovery in disciplinary proceedings against physician, 28 ALR3d 1440.

Comment note on hearsay evidence in proceedings before state administrative agencies, 36 ALR3d 12.

Entrapment as a defense in proceedings to revoke or suspend license to practice medicine, 61 ALR3d 357.

Applicability of statute of limitations or doctrine of laches to proceeding to revoke or suspend license to practice medicine, 51 ALR4th 1147.

Necessity of expert evidence in proceeding for revocation or suspension of license of physician, surgeon or dentist, 74 ALR4th 969.

§ 33-26-406. Reinstatement of license; removal of restrictions or conditions from a license.

  1. A person whose license has been voluntarily relinquished, revoked, restricted or suspended, or had conditions or restrictions placed upon his license, voluntarily or by action of the board, may petition for reinstatement of his license or for removal of any restrictions or conditions placed upon his license pursuant to W.S. 33-26-405 not less than six (6) months after final judicial review of a board order accepting relinquishment of, or revoking, restricting, placing conditions upon or suspending the petitioner’s license or six (6) months after the date of the board order if there is no judicial review.
  2. The petitioner shall submit a petition in writing to the board that, at a minimum, sets forth and provides information regarding the petitioner’s fulfillment of any and all conditions or compliance with all restrictions imposed upon petitioner by any prior order of the board or success in correcting the conduct that formed the basis for revocation or relinquishment of petitioner’s license.
  3. Upon receipt of the petition, the board shall set the matter for hearing in accordance with the provisions of the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. The burden of proof upon the petitioner at the hearing shall be to demonstrate, by a preponderance of evidence, that:
    1. Petitioner has corrected the conduct that formed the basis for the revocation or relinquishment of petitioner’s license and that petitioner is able to safely, skillfully and competently resume the practice of medicine; or
    2. Petitioner has fulfilled all conditions or complied with all restrictions imposed upon petitioner by any prior order of the board, has otherwise corrected the conduct or condition which formed the basis for the restrictions or conditions placed on petitioner’s license and is able to safely, skillfully and competently practice medicine in this state.
  4. After a hearing conducted pursuant to subsection (c) of this section, the board shall issue specific findings of facts, conclusions of law and a final order:
    1. Reinstating the license;
    2. Reinstating the license subject to restrictions or conditions;
    3. Removing or modifying the restrictions or conditions of the license; or
    4. Denying reinstatement of the license or removal of the restrictions or conditions on the license.
  5. Any final order issued by the board hereunder shall be subject to judicial review as provided for by W.S. 33-26-407 .
  6. If the board denies a reinstatement or removal of restrictions or conditions, future petitions for reinstatement or removal of restrictions or conditions may be submitted not less than one (1) year after the board’s final order denying reinstatement or removal of restrictions or conditions.
  7. Notwithstanding subsections (a) through (d) of this section, if a license is suspended under W.S. 33-26-404(d), the license may be reissued without a hearing as provided in this section upon receipt from the department of family services of notice that the applicant has complied with the terms of the court order that resulted in the suspension or restriction of the license under W.S. 33-26-404(d).

History. Laws 1976, ch. 24, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 33-340.11; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-137; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1995, ch. 129, § 1; 1997, ch. 128, § 2; 2003, ch. 190, § 2; 2009, ch. 201, § 1.

The 2009 amendment, in (a), susbstituted “has been voluntarily relinquished, revoked, restricted or suspended, or had conditions or restrictions placed upon his license” for “has been revoked, restricted or suspended under this chapter” near the beginning and substituted “board order accepting relinquishment of, or revoking, restricting, placing conditions upon” for “board order revoking, restricting” near the end; and inserted “or relinquishment” in (b) and (c)(i).

Laws 2009, ch. 201, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 12, 2009.

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

See § 16-3-101(a), (b)(xi) and notes thereto.

§ 33-26-407. Judicial review.

  1. Judicial review of the findings of the board may be obtained pursuant to the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. All final administrative orders of the board shall remain effective pending any judicial review, except where the board finds that the licensee’s continued practice presents no danger to the public.
  2. In any disciplinary proceeding against a licensee, the board shall bear the burden of proving a violation of this act by clear and convincing evidence.

History. Laws 1976, ch. 24, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 33-340.12; W.S. 1977, § 33-26-138; Laws 1987, ch. 79, § 1; 1991, ch. 143, § 1; 1995, ch. 129, § 1; 2003, ch. 190, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to judicial review of administrative action generally, see Rule 12, W.R.A.P., and Rule 87(b), W.R.C.P.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-26-102(a)(xxi).

Subsection (b) unconstitutional. —

In disciplinary proceedings, the board must prove disciplinary cases by clear and convincing evidence; therefore, subsection (b) of this section is unconstitutional on both equal protection and due process grounds. Painter v. Abels, 998 P.2d 931, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 42 (Wyo. 2000).

It is presumed that board action was right. —

The presumption is that members of the board are assumed to be men of conscience and intellectual discipline, capable of judging a particular controversy fairly on the basis of its own circumstances. It is also presumed the action of the board was right. The burden is on the challenging party to overcome the presumptions. Fallon v. Wyoming State Bd. of Medical Examiners, 441 P.2d 322, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 175 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 443 P.2d 135, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 177 (Wyo. 1968).

But requisite basic findings are not implied from ultimate findings. —

Where a limited right of review such as prevails in this state is granted from the decision of an administrative agency, such agency must find the basic facts upon which its decision rests. Unlike the rule observed in a proceeding tried in the district courts of this state, the requisite basic findings will not be implied from ultimate findings. Fallon v. Wyoming State Bd. of Medical Examiners, 441 P.2d 322, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 175 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 443 P.2d 135, 1968 Wyo. LEXIS 177 (Wyo. 1968).

Applied in

Taylor v. Wyoming Bd. of Medicine, 930 P.2d 973, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1996).

Law reviews. —

See “Scope of Review of Decision of an Administrative Agency in Wyoming,” 9 Wyo. L.J. 65 (1954).

See note, “De Novo Judicial Review of Wyoming Administrative Findings,” 15 Wyo. L.J. 67 (1960).

§ 33-26-408. Protected action and communication.

  1. There shall be no liability on the part of and no action for damages against:
    1. Board and examination committee members acting within the scope of their functions without malice and in the reasonable belief that their actions were warranted;
    2. Any person providing information voluntarily or pursuant to a subpoena, in good faith to a peer review committee or in good faith to the board or the examining committee without malice and in reasonable belief that the information is accurate.
  2. All board records shall be maintained and protected from harm.
  3. Final findings of fact, conclusions of law, orders of the board entered and any consent decree, stipulation or agreement to which the board is a party in any disciplinary docket of the board are public documents. The board may order, under special circumstances and upon entry of specific findings setting forth those circumstances, that a consent decree, stipulation or agreement to which the board is a party in any disciplinary docket is not a public document.
  4. The board shall promptly report and provide all final orders entered by it to the chief of the medical staff and hospital administrator of each hospital in which the licensee has medical staff privileges and to all appropriate agencies including the federation of state medical boards, the national practitioner data bank and other state medical boards.
  5. This section shall not be construed to prohibit the United States or the state of Wyoming from obtaining information from the board concerning a physician who is the subject of a criminal investigation. Upon petition to a state or federal district court, supported by affidavit, the judge may order the Wyoming board of medicine to release records of any proceedings, testimony of witnesses and reports or investigation for in-camera inspection by the judge, or the judge may deny the petition for failure to show good cause. The petition shall state the nature of the criminal investigation and the identity of the physician who is under investigation. If the judge grants the petition and orders the board to produce the board’s records for in-camera inspection, the board shall comply within ten (10) days after entry of the order or as otherwise ordered by the court. Upon receipt of the records, the judge shall inspect them to determine what material, if any, is relevant to the criminal investigation. Material deemed to be relevant shall be made available to the investigation if otherwise admissible under the Wyoming Rules of Evidence. All records and material deemed by the court to be irrelevant or otherwise inadmissible under the Wyoming Rules of Evidence shall be returned to the board and the contents thereof shall not be divulged.
  6.
