    32. “Material to the transaction” means having importance, relevance or consequence to a person making a decision regarding the purchase, sale or lease of real estate. “Material to the transaction” does not include psychological considerations including, but not limited to, health issues, suicide, murder or crimes which have occurred on the property;
    33. “Offer” means any inducement, solicitation or attempt to encourage a person to acquire an interest in real estate which is made for gain or profit;
    34. “Offeree” means a person to whom an offer is made;
    35. “Offeror” means the person making an offer;
    36. “Office” means a responsible broker’s place of business where records are maintained;
    37. “Option” is a right that an owner may give to another person to purchase or lease the owner’s real estate at a specific price;
    38. “Owner” means a person with a right to convey an ownership or leasehold interest in real estate;
    39. “Person” means individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations or other public or private entities, foreign or domestic;
    40. “Prior acts coverage” means insurance coverage for any claim made during a current policy period when the act or acts causing the claim or injuries for which the claim is made occurred prior to the inception of the current policy period;
    41. “Proof of coverage” means a certificate of insurance demonstrating coverage of a policy of insurance equal to or exceeding the group coverage contracted for by the commission;
    42. “Property management” means the act of management for compensation of real estate for another, including collection of rents, maintenance of the real estate and accounting of fees received for another;
    43. “Qualified insurance carrier” means an insurance carrier that:
      1. For the entire term of its contract shall provide the group plan of errors and omission insurance as provided in this act, maintains an A.M. Best rating of “B” or better and financial size category of class VI or higher;
      2. Is authorized by the Wyoming insurance department to do business in Wyoming as an insurance carrier for the policy term;
      3. Is and will remain qualified and authorized by the Wyoming insurance department to write policies of errors and omissions insurance in Wyoming for the policy term;
      4. After competitive bidding, has been notified by the commission that it is the successful bidder for the group plan to provide the errors and omissions insurance as specified in this act;
      5. Has entered into a contract to provide group errors and omissions plan in conformity with the contract, this act, applicable rules of the commission and other applicable law;
      6. Will collect premiums, maintain records and report names of those insured and a record of claims to the commission on a timely basis.
    44. “Real estate” means leaseholds, as well as any other interest or estate in land, whether corporeal, incorporeal, freehold or nonfreehold, and whether the real estate is situated in this state or elsewhere but shall not apply to nor include mineral lands, rights or leases;
    45. “Real estate activity” occurs when an individual for another and for compensation performs any one or more of the following:
      1. Sells, exchanges, purchases, rents, manages or leases real estate;
      2. Offers to sell, exchange, purchase, rent, manage or lease real estate;
      3. Negotiates, offers, attempts or agrees to negotiate the sale, exchange, purchase, rental or leasing of real estate;
      4. Lists, offers, attempts or agrees to list real estate for sale, lease or exchange;
      5. Auctions, offers, attempts or agrees to auction real estate;
      6. Collects, offers, attempts or agrees to collect rent for the use of real estate;
      7. Advertises or holds himself out as being engaged in the business of buying, selling, exchanging, auctioning, renting or leasing real estate;
      8. Engages in  the business of charging an advance fee in connection with any contract  undertaken to promote the sale, auction or lease of real estate either  through its listing in a publication issued for that purpose or for  referral of information concerning the real estate to responsible brokers, associate brokers and salespersons;
      9. Buys, sells, offers to buy or sell or otherwise deals in options on real estate or improvements thereon;
      10. Assists or directs in the procuring of prospects calculated to result in the sale, exchange, lease or rental of real estate;
      11. Assists or directs in the negotiation of any transaction calculated or intended to result in the sale, exchange, lease or rental of real estate;
      12. Deals in time shares;
      13. Provides a broker’s price opinion as provided in W.S. 33-28-125 .
    46. “Real  estate company” means a domestic  or foreign business entity that is authorized to conduct business in Wyoming and licensed by the commission to conduct real estate activity;
    47. “Real estate transaction” or “transaction” means any real estate activity under this section;
    48. “Regular employee” means an individual who is employed by an owner of real estate on a salaried basis or paid wages which are not performance based, is subject to income tax withholding and FICA and whose duties are performed in the ordinary course of the owner’s business or the management or operation of the owner’s investments;
    49. “Responsible  broker” means an individual who has an active responsible broker’s license and  who is responsible for the supervision of the activities of licensees  associated with the real estate company or a responsible broker who operates a single license office or sole proprietorship;
    50. “Retroactive date” means the date when the first real estate errors and omissions coverage was effective insuring the named insured on a claims-made basis and since which time the insured has been continuously insured;
    51. “Salesperson” means an individual who has qualified as  a salesperson under this act and is licensed by the commission under a responsible  broker;
    52. “Seller” means a person who is attempting to sell or exchange real estate and includes a landlord as that term is commonly used in the rental, leasing or management of real estate;
    53. “Seller’s agent” means a licensee who is authorized to represent and act for the seller in a real estate transaction;
    54. “Short term rental” means the rental of real estate for thirty-one (31) days or less;
    55. “Single-limit liability” means the maximum limit payable, per licensee, for damages arising out of the same error, omission or wrongful act;
    56. “Subagent” means a licensee authorized to represent and act on behalf of a real estate company in performing real estate activity for a principal. A subagent shall owe the same obligations and responsibilities to the principal as a responsible broker;
    57. “Surrendered license” means a license that has been voluntarily terminated or surrendered by a licensee who, at the time of the voluntary termination or surrender, was under investigation or named in a formal administrative complaint and the surrender has been accepted by the commission;
    58. “Suspended license” means a license that has been temporarily suspended by the issuing authority;
    59. “Time share” means any arrangement, whether by membership agreement, lease, rental agreement, license, use agreement or other means, whereby the purchaser receives a right to use or a freehold interest in accommodations, facilities or other real estate for a specific period of time during any given year, but not necessarily for consecutive years, and which extends for a period of more than one (1) year;
    60. “Transaction manager” means a licensee designated in writing by the responsible broker to supervise a transaction. The transaction manager shall not be involved in the transaction and shall have the duties of an intermediary while supervising the transaction;
    61. “Written listing agreement” means any real estate employment agreement, including without limitation a buyer’s brokerage agreement, a seller’s listing contract and a property management contract. The authority created under a written listing agreement may not be assigned to another person without the written consent of all parties to the agreement;
    62. “Broker’s price opinion” means an estimate prepared by a licensee that details the probable selling price of real estate and provides a varying level of detail about the real estate’s condition, market and neighborhood and information about sales of comparable real estate;
    63. “This act” means W.S. 33-28-101 through 33-28-401 .

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 2; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.2; Laws 1973, ch. 152, § 1; 1983, ch. 156, §§ 2, 3; 2008, ch. 2, § 1; 2011, ch. 104, §§ 1, 2; 2012, ch. 68, § 2; 2017, ch. 166, §§ 1, 2.

Cross references. —

As to relationships between brokers and the public, see § 33-28-302 .

The 2008 amendment, substituted “33-28-401” for “33-28-206” in (a)(xviii).

Laws 2008, ch. 2, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2008.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, repealed former (a), which defined terms; and added (b).

The 2012 amendment, effective July 1, 2012, added “performs any one or more of the following” in the introductory language of (b)(xlv); added (b)(xlv)(O) and made related changes; and added (b)(lxii) and redesignated former (b)(lxii) as (b)(lxiii).

The 2017 amendments. — The first 2017 amendment, by ch. 166, § 1, effective July 1, 2017, in (b)(iv), substituted “an associate broker” for “a broker,” added “by the commission”; rewrote (b)(vi) which formerly read: “‘Branch office’ means any office of a responsible broker other than his principal place of business; in (b)(xxix), added “by the person’s legal name”; in (b)(xlv)(H) substituted “responsible brokers, associate brokers and salespersons” for “brokers”; rewrote (b)(xlvi) which formerly read: “‘Real estate company’ means a business entity including a firm, company, corporation, partnership, sole proprietorship or other entity which is licensed to conduct real estate activity”; in (b)(xlix) added “responsible” before “broker’s license” and “sole proprietorship” at the end; in (b)(li), added “by the commission,” substituted gender-neutral terms, and made related changes.

The second 2017 amendment, by ch. 166, § 2, effective July 1, 2017, deleted (b)(vii), which read: ““Broker” means any person licensed under this act including associate brokers and responsible brokers. “Broker” does not include a salesman.”

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subparagraph (b)(xlv)(I) or (b)(xlv)(L) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

For meaning of “regular employee” prior to 1983 amendment of this section. —

See Battlefield, Inc. v. Neely, 656 P.2d 1154, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 271 (Wyo. 1983).

Real estate agent, not acting as agent, not held to standard of agent. —

The daughter-in-law of the seller of certain property, who was a licensed real estate agent, and who was “helping out” her mother-in-law in the sales transaction, but who never met the buyers in person, who did not obtain loan information, show houses to them, convey offers to purchase, negotiate the sales price or terms of sale, develop a close relationship with the buyers, list the property or show it or sell it, and who was not paid a commission, was not acting as a real estate agent and was not held to the standard of a real estate agent. Walter v. Moore, 700 P.2d 1219, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 485 (Wyo. 1985).

Commission not earned by broker. —

Where broker had not been employed to sell defendant's property, he could not, by securing a purchaser, notifying defendants of that fact, and requesting protection on his commission, render defendants liable to him for commission on sale made direct to such customer. Stevens v. Brimmer, 35 Wyo. 452, 251 P. 1, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1926).

Contract with unlicensed broker is void. —

Where a person was not a licensed real estate broker in the state of Wyoming, the contract between that person and another to sell a business, the assets of which included leases from an airport board, was void and any actions taken by the unlicensed person to sell the business were unlawful and the unlicensed person was prevented from bringing action for his commission under the laws of Wyoming. Doran v. Imeson Aviation, Inc., 419 F. Supp. 586, 1976 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13489 (D. Wyo. 1976).

Quoted in

Bowlerama, Inc. v. Woodside Realty Co., 752 P.2d 1377, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 1988).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Real Estate Brokers and Salespersons — When is a Broker Not a Broker? Walter v. Moore, 700 P.2d 1219, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 485 (Wyo. 1985),” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 241 (1986).

§ 33-28-103. Exemptions.

  1. The provisions of this act shall not apply to:
    1. An owner of real estate or to a member of his immediate family or to his regular employees with respect to property owned by him unless the owner, his immediate family or regular employee is a licensee;
    2. An attorney in fact under a duly executed and recorded power of attorney to convey real estate from the owner or lessor, or the services rendered by an attorney-at-law in the performance of his duties as an attorney unless the attorney is a licensee;
    3. Any individual acting as receiver, trustee in bankruptcy, administrator, executor, or guardian, or while acting under a court order or under the authority of a will or of a trust instrument or as a witness in any judicial proceeding or other proceeding conducted by the state or any governmental subdivision or agency unless that individual is a licensee;
    4. Any officer or employee of a federal agency in the conduct of his official duties, unless that individual is a licensee;
    5. Any officer or employee of the state government or any political subdivision thereof performing his official duties, unless that individual is a licensee;
    6. Any person or employee acting as the resident manager for the owner or an employee acting as the resident manager for a responsible broker managing an apartment building, duplex, apartment complex or court, when the resident manager resides on the premises and is engaged in the leasing of real estate in connection with his employment, unless that individual is a licensee; or
    7. A home owner’s association formed and acting pursuant to its declaration and bylaws or a resort association formed and acting pursuant to its association agreement and bylaws.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 3; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.3; Laws 1973, ch. 152, § 1; 1983, ch. 156, § 2; 2009, ch. 63, § 1; 2011, ch. 104, § 1; 2017, ch. 166, § 1.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, added “unless the owner, his immediate family or regular employee is a licensee” following “owned by him” in (a)(i), and added “unless the attorney is a licensee” following “attorney” in (a)(ii).

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a)(iii) through (a)(vi), added “unless that individual is a licensee,” and substituted “real estate” for “property” in (a)(vi).

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, in (a)(vi) substituted “responsible broker” for “broker.”

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

Meaning of “regular employee” prior to 1983 amendment of § 33-28-102 . —

See Battlefield, Inc. v. Neely, 656 P.2d 1154, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 271 (Wyo. 1983).

Cited in

McCoy v. Thompson, 677 P.2d 839, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 265 (Wyo. 1984).

Library references. —

17 Nat. Resources & Env't Law Review 95.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Right of attorney, as such, to act or become licensed to act as real-estate broker, 23 ALR4th 230.

§ 33-28-104. Acts constituting person as licensee.

Any person who, for another, with the intention or upon the promise of receiving compensation offers, attempts or agrees to perform, or performs any single act of real estate activity, whether as a part of a transaction or as the entire transaction shall be deemed to be acting as a licensee within the meaning of this act.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 4; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.4; Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 2; 2011, ch. 104, § 1.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, substituted “compensation” for “any valuable consideration,” substituted “of real estate activity” for “defined in W.S. 33-28-102(a)(iii),” and substituted “licensee” for “broker, associate broker or salesman.”

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

Real estate agent, not acting as agent, not held to standard of agent. —

The daughter-in-law of the seller of certain property, who was a licensed real estate agent, and who was “helping out” her mother-in-law in the sales transaction, but who never met the buyers in person, who did not obtain loan information, show houses to them, convey offers to purchase, negotiate the sales price or terms of sale, develop a close relationship with the buyers, list the property or show it or sell it, and who was not paid a commission, was not acting as a real estate agent and was not held to the standard of a real estate agent. Walter v. Moore, 700 P.2d 1219, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 485 (Wyo. 1985).

Stated in

Bowlerama, Inc. v. Woodside Realty Co., 752 P.2d 1377, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 1988).

Cited in

McCoy v. Thompson, 677 P.2d 839, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 265 (Wyo. 1984).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Real Estate Brokers and Salespersons — When is a Broker Not a Broker? Walter v. Moore, 700 P.2d 1219, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 485 (Wyo. 1985),” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 241 (1986).

§ 33-28-105. Creation of commission; membership; terms; removal; chairman; powers and duties; director and duties thereof; other employees; compensation; disposition of fees.

  1. The Wyoming real estate commission is created to consist of five (5) commissioners, each of whom shall be a citizen of Wyoming, appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the senate. Not less than three (3) or more than four (4) of the membership shall have been engaged in business as a licensee in Wyoming for at least five (5) years immediately preceding appointment. No more than one (1) commissioner shall be appointed from the same county to serve at the same time. The term of the members of the commission shall be for three (3) years and until their successors are appointed and qualified. Members appointed to fill vacancies shall be appointed in accordance with W.S. 28-12-101 , and no member shall be appointed to succeed himself for more than one (1) full term. The governor may remove any commission member as provided in W.S. 9-1-202 . The commission at its first meeting held after September 1 of each year shall select a chairman to serve for the following year. The commission has the power to regulate the issuance of licenses, to revoke or suspend licenses issued under this act, to censure licensees and may do all things necessary and proper to carry out the provisions of this act. The commission may, from time to time, promulgate and amend necessary and reasonable rules and regulations for these purposes. Appointments and terms shall be in accordance with W.S. 28-12-101 through 28-12-103 .
  2. Repealed by Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 3.
  3. The commission shall employ a director. The director is subject to the rules and regulations of the human resources division of the department of administration and information. The director’s salary shall be paid from the real estate commission account specified in subsection (g) of this section. The duties of the director shall include the following:
    1. Maintain and operate a suitable office for the commission;
    2. Keep books, records and accounts of all activities of the commission;
    3. Issue real estate responsible broker, associate broker, salesperson and real estate company licenses;
    4. Make investigations of complaints and possible violations of the real estate laws and practices of licensees and to furnish information and recommendations to the commission for their action;
    5. Assist the commission with examinations to be given applicants for real estate licenses, and to conduct the examinations at the direction of the commission;
    6. Assist the commission in holding educational clinics or meetings when deemed advisable with the aim of promoting higher standards of practice in the real estate profession;
    7. Assist the commission in promulgating rules in compliance with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act [§§ 16-3-101 through 16-3-115 ], for the operation of the commission and the implementation of this law; and
    8. Perform other duties as the commission prescribes.
  4. The commission shall employ other staff members to assist in the discharge of the duties imposed upon it by this act and shall prescribe the duties and fix the compensation of its staff members, subject to the rules and regulations of the human resources division of the department of administration and information. The office of the commission shall be maintained in Cheyenne and all files, records and property of the commission shall at all times remain in the Cheyenne office. No commission staff member may be a paid employee of any real estate association, real estate company or real estate licensee.
  5. Each member of the commission shall receive compensation from the real estate commission account for each day actually spent on his official duties including per diem and mileage as provided in W.S. 33-1-302(a)(vii) and salary in the amount provided by W.S. 28-5-101(d) for the performance of official duties.
  6. The commission shall adopt a seal, including the words Wyoming Real Estate Commission, Office of the Commission by which the acts of the commission shall be authenticated. Copies of all records and papers in the office of the commission, certified by the signature of the director and the seal of the commission, shall be received in evidence in all cases equally and with like effect as the originals.
  7. All fees collected by the commission shall be deposited in the state treasury. The state treasurer shall deposit the fees to the credit of the real estate commission account. Disbursements from the account shall not exceed the monies credited to it.
  8. The presence of three (3) members of the commission shall constitute a quorum. In the absence of the chairman, the member of the commission present who is senior in time of service shall serve as the presiding officer. The action of the majority of the members of the commission shall be deemed the action of the commission.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 5; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.5; Laws 1973, ch. 179, § 1; ch. 245, § 3; 1977, ch. 147, § 1; 1979, ch. 17, § 2; 1983, ch. 156, §§ 2, 3; 1987, ch. 175, § 1; 1991, ch. 29, § 3; 1997, ch. 178, § 1; 2005, ch. 231, § 1; 2009, ch. 63, § 1; 2011, ch. 104, § 1; 2014, ch. 69, § 2; 2017, ch. 166, § 1.

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, deleted “within the earmarked revenue fund” following “real estate board account” in (c), (e), and (g).

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (e), deleted “, twenty dollars ($20.00) and” preceding “per diem” and inserted “and salary in the amount provided by W.S. 28-5-101(d)” following “state employees”.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a), substituted “a licensee” for “an active salesperson or broker,” added “to serve at the same time,” and deleted “Effective July 1, 1979” at the beginning of the last sentence; in the introductory language of (c) and in (e) and (g), substituted “commission” for “board”; in (c)(v), deleted “broker and salesman” after “real estate”; in (e), added “including,” and made stylistic changes; in (f), deleted the former last three sentences, which read: “The presence of three (3) members of the commission shall constitute a quorum. In the absence of the chairman, the member of the commission present who is senior in time of service shall serve as presiding officer. The action of the majority of the members of the commission shall be deemed the action of the commission”; and added (h).

The 2014 amendment, effective July 1, 2014, in (e), substituted “as provided in W.S. 33-1-302(a)(vii)” for “allowance as allowed for state employees.”

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, rewrote (c)(iii), which formerly read: “Issue real estate broker licenses”; in (d) substituted “staff member” for “employees” or variants, and substituted “real estate company or real estate licensee” for “or group of real estate dealers or brokers”; and made related changes.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2005, ch. 231, § 3, provides: “The provisions of this act shall supersede the provisions of any other bill enacted into law during the 2005 general session which amends or references accounts or funds to the extent any other enactment is inconsistent with the establishment of the funds and accounts created under this act. The state auditor shall account for any fund or account created in any other legislation enacted in the 2005 general session in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) as promulgated by the governmental accounting standards board (GASB) and in accordance with this act.”

Applied in

Battlefield, Inc. v. Neely, 656 P.2d 1154, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 271 (Wyo. 1983).

Law reviews. —

For article, “A State Central Panel Hearing Officer System for Wyoming,” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 497 (1986).

§ 33-28-106. Application for license; qualifications; sworn statement; commission approval of course of study; statement of responsible broker; denial of license; issuing licenses.

  1. Any person desiring to act as a licensee shall file an application for a license with the commission. The application shall be in the form and detail as the commission shall prescribe and the individual applicant shall provide to the commission fingerprints and other information necessary for a criminal history record background check as provided in W.S. 7-19-201(a).
  2. Licenses shall be granted only to persons who bear a good reputation for honesty, trustworthiness, integrity and competence to transact the business of a licensee in a manner which will safeguard the interests of the public, and only after satisfactory proof of the individual applicant’s qualifications has been presented to the commission.
  3. Each applicant for a responsible broker’s license shall:
    1. Have reached the age of majority;
    2. Have first served actively for two (2) of the four (4) years immediately preceding the application as a real estate salesperson or associate broker; and
    3. Submit other evidence through the application or otherwise, as the commission deems desirable with due regard to the paramount interests of the public, as to the honesty, truthfulness, integrity and competency of the individual applicant.
  4. Every member of a real estate company acting as a responsible broker for that real estate company who engages in any real estate activity shall obtain a responsible broker’s license.
  5. Every applicant for a responsible broker’s or associate broker’s license shall state:
    1. The name of the real estate company with which he will be associated in the business of real estate;
    2. The location of the place or places for which the license is desired;
    3. The period of time, if any, which he has been engaged in the real estate business;
    4. His present address, both of business and residence;
    5. Repealed by Laws 2005, ch. 96, § 2.
    6. That he has or has not been refused a real estate license in this or any other state;
    7. That his real estate license has or has not been revoked in this or any other state;
    8. Evidence that he has completed not less than sixty (60) cumulative class hours in a course of study approved by the commission, given by instructors approved by the commission and has satisfactorily passed an examination covering material taught in each course.
      1. through (D) Repealed by Laws 2011, ch. 104, § 2.
  6. Each applicant for a salesperson’s license shall:
    1. through (vii) Repealed by Laws 2011, ch. 104, § 2.
    2. Have reached the age of majority;
    3. Submit other evidence as the commission deems desirable with due regard to the paramount interests of the public as to the honesty, truthfulness, integrity and competency of the individual applicant;
    4. Furnish the name of the real estate company with which he will be associated in the business of real estate;
    5. Furnish the period of time, if any, that he has been engaged in the real estate business;
    6. Furnish his present address;
    7. Furnish the name and address of his previous employer;
    8. Furnish a statement that he has or has not been refused a real estate license in this or any other state;
    9. Furnish a statement that his real estate license has or has not been revoked in this or any other state;
    10. Furnish evidence that he has completed not less than thirty (30) class hours in a course of study approved by the commission, given by instructors approved by the commission and has satisfactorily passed an examination covering material taught in each course;
    11. Include a statement by the responsible broker in whose service the applicant is about to enter stating:
      1. The name and address of the responsible broker’s real estate company;
      2. That in his opinion the applicant is honest, truthful and recommends the license be granted to the applicant;
      3. That the responsible broker will actively supervise and train the applicant during the period the requested license remains in effect.
  7. The commission may consider prior revocation, conduct or conviction in its determination of whether to grant an applicant a license if the applicant:
    1. Has been fined or disciplined or had his real estate license revoked, suspended, censured or placed on probation in any jurisdiction;
    2. Is found to have committed any of the practices enumerated in W.S. 33-28-111 during the term of his prior licensure; or
    3. Has been convicted of any felony that relates to the practice of real estate activity or to the ability to practice the duties of a responsible real estate licensee or any felony sexual offense or violent crime.
  8. The commission shall take into account the nature of the offense, any aggravating or extenuating circumstances, the time elapsed since the revocation, conduct or conviction, the rehabilitation or restitution performed by the applicant and other factors as the commission deems relevant.
  9. The commission may deny a license to any person who has been determined by the commission after hearing to have engaged in a licensed real estate activity without a license.
  10. The commission shall issue licenses in a form and size as the commission shall prescribe.
  11. A false statement of material fact made in an application shall in itself be sufficient grounds for the refusal of a license.
  12. Each individual applicant for an associate broker’s license shall:
    1. Have reached the age of majority;
    2. Have first served actively for two (2) of the four (4) years immediately preceding the application as a salesperson or shall furnish to the commission proof indicating that the applicant holds a degree in real estate from an accredited university or college; and
    3. Submit other evidence through the application or otherwise, as the commission deems desirable with due regard to the paramount interests of the public as to the honesty, truthfulness, integrity and competency of the individual applicant.
  13. The commission shall:
    1. Approve courses that cover real estate principles, real estate law, real estate finance and related topics;
    2. Promulgate rules and regulations to provide a process for challenging a course in lieu of evidence of completion of class hours;
    3. Publish a list of approved real estate courses and keep the list updated annually;
    4. On request, evaluate a specific course or courses which are not on the approved list and approve or disapprove the course.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 6; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.6; Laws 1973, ch. 213, § 2; 1983, ch. 156, § 2; 2005, ch. 96, § 2; 2006, ch. 114, § 1; 2009, ch. 63, § 1; 2011, ch. 104, §§ 1, 2; 2017, ch. 166, § 1; 2018, ch. 107, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to the Wyoming real estate commission, see § 33-28-105 .

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, repealed former (e)(v), which required an applicant for a broker's license to furnish in his sworn statement a complete list of all former places where he may have resided or been engaged in business for a period of 60 days or more during the last five years.

The 2006 amendment, inserted “real” in (e)(viii)(A).

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 24, 2006.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, added “and the applicant shall provide to the commission fingerprints and other information necessary for a criminal history record background check as provided in W.S. 7-19-201(a)” following “prescribe” in (a); and added “including a criminal history record background check as provided in W.S. 7-19-201(a)” following “commission” in (b).

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a) and (b), substituted “licensee” for “real estate broker, associate broker or real estate salesman” or similar language, and added “individual”; in (b), deleted “including a criminal history record background check as provided in W.S. 7-19-201(a)” after “to the commission”; in (c), made changes to credentials required for applicants for broker's license, and made stylistic changes; in (d), made stylistic changes; in (e), made stylistic changes, and repealed former (e)(viii)(A) through (e)(viii)(D), which listed the commission's duties regarding the course of study for prospective brokers; rewrote (f), to restate the information to be included in the applicant's written statement by deleting former (f)(i) through (f)(vii) and adding (f)(viii) through (f)(xvii); in (g), made a stylistic change in the introductory language; rewrote (g)(i), which formerly read: “Has had his real estate license revoked on a prior occasion”; in (k), substituted “licenses” for “to each broker and to each salesman licensee a license and pocket card”; and added (n) and (o).

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, substituted gender-neutral terms throughout.

The 2018 amendment, effective July 1, 2018, in (g)(iii), added “that relates to the practice of real estate activity or to the ability to practice the duties of a responsible real estate licensee or any felony sexual offense or violent crime” at the end.

Editor's notes. —

Conflicting Legislation. —

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 3, provides: “[A]ny other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Real Estate Brokers and Salespersons — When is a Broker Not a Broker? Walter v. Moore, 700 P.2d 1219, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 485 (Wyo. 1985),” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 241 (1986).

§ 33-28-107. Examinations; responsible broker, associate broker and salesperson’s licenses.

  1. In addition to proof of honesty, trustworthiness and good reputation, each applicant desiring to become licensed as a real estate responsible broker, associate broker or a real estate salesperson shall execute and file an application for examination upon a form prescribed by the commission and shall pass a written examination prepared by or under the supervision of the commission. The examination shall be given at times and at places within the state as the commission shall prescribe. The examination for a salesperson’s license shall include business ethics, composition, arithmetic, elementary principles of land economics and appraisal, a general knowledge of the statutes of this state relating to deeds, mortgages, contracts of sale, agency and the provisions of this act. The examinations for responsible broker and associate broker’s licenses shall be of a more exacting nature and scope and more stringent than the examination for a salesperson’s license.
  2. No applicant shall engage in real estate activity until he has satisfactorily passed the examination, complied with the other requirements of this act and until a license has been issued to him.
  3. Repealed by Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 3.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 7; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.7; Laws 1977, ch. 146, § 1; 1983, ch. 156, §§ 2, 3; 2011, ch. 104, § 1; 2017, ch. 166, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to the Wyoming real estate commission, see § 33-28-105 .

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (b), substituted “real estate activity” for “the real estate business either as a broker or salesman.”

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, substituted “responsible broker, associate broker” for “broker” or variants throughout the text, substituted “The examinations” for “The examination” at the beginning of the last sentence, and substituted gender-neutral terms.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Real Estate Brokers and Salespersons — When is a Broker Not a Broker? Walter v. Moore, 700 P.2d 1219, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 485 (Wyo. 1985),” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 241 (1986).

§ 33-28-108. Fees.

Pursuant to W.S. 33-1-201 , the commission shall establish fees for examinations, original licenses, modified licenses, renewals, certifications, change of place of business and transfers. The fees shall be used to pay the expense of maintaining and operating the office of the commission and the enforcement of this act.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 8; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.8; Laws 1973, ch. 245, § 3; 1983, ch. 156, § 2; 1992, ch. 56, § 2; 2011, ch. 104, § 1; 2017, ch. 166, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to the Wyoming real estate commission, see § 33-28-105 .

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, substituted “and duplicate licenses” for “duplicate licenses and duplicate pocket cards.”

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, rewrote the first sentence, which formerly read: “Pursuant to W.S. 33-1-201 , the commission shall establish fees for examinations, original licenses, renewals, certifications, change of place of business, transfers and duplicate licenses.”

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in the second sentence, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

§ 33-28-109. Responsible broker to establish a real estate company, maintain fixed principal office; change of address; branch offices; restrictions on associate brokers and salespersons.

  1. Each resident responsible broker shall lawfully establish at least one (1) but no more than three (3) real estate companies or sole proprietorships within Wyoming and acquire a license for each real estate company or sole proprietorship. Each resident responsible broker shall maintain a fixed principal office for each company or sole proprietorship within this state. The address of each office shall be designated on all licenses associated with the office and no license issued under this act shall authorize the licensee to transact real estate activity at any other address except a licensed branch office. In case of removal from a designated address, the responsible broker shall apply to the commission before the removal designating the new location of an office and paying the required fee, whereupon the commission shall issue a license for the new location for the unexpired period if the new location complies with the terms of this act.
  2. A responsible broker may conduct business from a branch office. A branch office shall use the same trade name or business name as the licensed real estate company. A company license shall be issued to the responsible broker for each branch office the responsible broker maintains. Every branch office shall be under the direction and supervision of the responsible broker. A responsible broker requesting a branch office license shall also, in addition to the branch office application, submit a plan of supervision for the branch office for approval by the commission.
  3. An associate broker or salesperson shall not be associated or engaged under contract to any other responsible broker than is designated upon the license issued to the associate broker or salesperson. Upon termination of an associate broker’s or salesperson’s association or contractual relationship, his responsible broker shall immediately notify the commission for cancellation of the associate broker’s or salesperson’s license. Whenever a licensed associate broker or salesperson desires to change his contractual relationship from one (1) responsible broker to another, he shall notify the commission promptly in writing of the facts attendant thereon and pay the required fee. Upon application, the commission shall issue a new license under the new responsible broker. No associate broker or salesperson shall directly or indirectly associate himself with a responsible broker until he has been issued a license to do so with that responsible broker.
  4. No more than one (1) license to conduct real estate activity shall be issued to any responsible broker, associate broker or salesperson to be in effect at one (1) time except as provided in subsection (a) of this section.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 9; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.9; Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 2; 2007, ch. 171, § 1; 2011, ch. 104, § 1; 2017, ch. 166, § 1.

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, in (b) deleted “who resides in the community in which the branch office is located” from the second sentence.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, rewrote (a) and (b) , deleting need to display licenses in office, and making stylistic changes; and rewrote (c), providing for steps that an associate broker or salesman must take upon termination of their association or contractual relationship, and making stylistic changes.

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, in (a) added “shall lawfully…sole proprietorship” to the first sentence, added “each resident responsible broker,” “principle,” and “for each company or sole proprietorship” to the second sentence, and substituted “each” for “the” in the third sentence; in (b) deleted “If a responsible broker maintains more than one (1) place of business within the state, a branch office” from the first sentence, added “A responsible broker may conduct business from a branch office” to the first sentence, added the second sentence, added “A company” to the beginning of the third sentence, and substituted “the responsible broker maintains” for “so maintained by him” in the third sentence; in (d) added “to conduct real estate activity” toward the beginning, substituted “responsible broker, associate broker or salesperson” for “salesman,” and added “except as provided in subsection(a) of this section” to the end; made stylistic changes; substituted gender-neutral terms, and made related changes.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

§ 33-28-110. Unlawful to compensate unlicensed person; licensing of like-licensed nonresidents; service of process on nonresidents.

  1. It is unlawful for any responsible broker to compensate any person who is not a licensee associated with his real estate company or a responsible broker for another real estate company for performing any real estate activity provided, however, that a responsible broker may pay compensation to a licensed broker of another state if the nonresident broker does not conduct any real estate activity in this state for which compensation is paid.
  2. A nonresident may be issued a Wyoming responsible broker’s license if:
    1. The individual holds a like-license in his home state;
    2. The individual is actively engaged in the real estate business and maintains a place of business in his home state;
    3. The individual meets all the other requirements of this act and rules and regulations of the commission; and
    4. The individual furnishes the commission a statement under seal of the commission of his home state evidencing that he is an active licensed responsible broker, or an equivalent, in good standing and has no complaints pending against him in his home state.
  3. Repealed by Laws 2011, ch. 104, § 2.
  4. A nonresident may be issued a Wyoming associate broker or salesperson license if:
    1. The individual holds a like-license in his home state;
    2. The individual is actively engaged in the real estate business in his home state;
    3. The individual meets all the other requirements of this act and rules and regulations of the commission; and
    4. The individual furnishes the commission a statement under seal of the commission of his home state evidencing that he holds an active license in good standing and has no complaints pending against him in his home state.
  5. Repealed by Laws 2007, ch. 171, § 2.
  6. Prior to being issued a license, every nonresident licensee shall file with the commission a designation in writing which appoints the director of the commission to act as his licensed agent upon whom all judicial and other process or legal notices directed to the licensee may be served. Service upon the agent so designated shall be equivalent to personal service upon the licensee. Copies of the appointment, certified by the director of the commission, shall be received in evidence in any proceeding and shall be given the same force and effect as the original. In the written designation the licensee shall agree that any lawful process against the licensee which is served upon his appointed agent shall be of the same legal force and validity as if served upon the licensee, and that the authority of the agent shall continue in force so long as any liability of the licensee remains outstanding in this state. Upon the receipt of any process or notice, the director shall mail a copy of the same by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known business address of the licensee.
  7. through (j) Repealed by Laws 2011, ch. 104, § 2.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 10; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.10; Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 2; 2007, ch. 171, § 2; 2011, ch. 104, §§ 1, 2; 2017, ch. 166, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to the Wyoming real estate commission, see § 33-28-105 .

The 2007 amendment, effective July 1, 2007, repealed former (e), which read: “If a nonresident licensee becomes a resident of this state or if he desires to maintain a place of business in this state, or be employed by or associated with a broker maintaining a place of business in this state he shall secure a regular resident license in compliance with this act and rules governing original resident applicants. If an applicant's home state requires a resident of this state to maintain a place of business in that state in order to transact business in that state, the applicant shall maintain a place of business in this state and need not secure a regular resident license to maintain a place of business in this state in order to transact business in this state. A nonresident of this state shall meet the same rules and requirements of his resident state in order to obtain a reciprocal license in this state.”

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a), made stylistic changes; substituted “Wyoming responsible” for “nonresident Wyoming” in the introductory language of (b); in (b)(i), substituted “holds a like-license” for “is a licensed broker”; in (b)(iii), added “and rules and regulations of the commission”; substituted (b)(iv) for former (b)(iv) which read: “The individual's home state has entered into a reciprocal agreement with the commission relating to the issuance of reciprocal licenses”; repealed former (c), which provided conditions under which a nonresident broker's license may be issued without examination to a real estate broker licensed under the laws of another state”; rewrote (d) providing the conditions under which a nonresident may be issued a Wyoming license; in (f), substituted “licensee” for “broker”; and repealed former (g) through (j), which provided for written agreement by the nonresident broker to abide by provisions of act and submit to jurisdiction of commission, providing for nonresident broker to file proof of authorization to conduct business in any other state and pay license fee, and conditions for nonresident licenses to remain in force.

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, in (b)(iv) at the beginning substituted “individual” for “broker” and substituted “licensed responsible broker, or an equivalent” for “licensed broker;” and in (d) substituted gender-neutral terms.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (i) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

Effect of agreement to share on suit for commission. —

In an action by a licensed broker for his commission for sale of real estate, fact that broker had agreed to share his commission with an unlicensed person was held of no consequence. Foley v. Hassey, 55 Wyo. 24, 95 P.2d 85, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1939) (decided under prior law).

Out-of-state broker may cooperate with in-state broker. —

The purpose of this chapter, protecting the public, is not violated when a broker, licensed in another state, cooperates with a broker licensed in this state, where a sale occurs, in procuring a purchaser, but does not actually conduct negotiations in Wyoming. Bowlerama, Inc. v. Woodside Realty Co., 752 P.2d 1377, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 1988), reh'g denied, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. Apr. 28, 1988).

§ 33-28-111. Censure of licensee and suspension or revocation of license; grounds.

  1. The commission shall upon a written sworn complaint or may upon its own motion investigate the actions of any licensee conducting real estate advertising, self promotion as a licensee or real estate activity regarding real estate located in Wyoming, impose an administrative fine not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for each separate offense and may censure a licensee, place a licensee on probation and set the terms of probation, suspend or revoke any license issued under this act for any of the following:
    1. Making any substantial misrepresentation, false promises or false or fraudulent representation;
    2. Violation of this act or any rule of the commission;
    3. Failing to disclose an interest in the transaction;
    4. Soliciting the breach of a listing or a property management contract;
    5. Conducting real estate activity directly with a buyer or seller if the licensee knows the buyer or seller has an outstanding written agreement in connection with the real estate with another responsible broker;
    6. Using advertising which:
      1. Is misleading or is inaccurate in any matter material to the transaction; or
      2. Uses a trade name, collective membership mark, service mark or logo name, mark or logo without authorization owned by another person unless authorized to do so.
    7. Placing a sign on any property offering it for sale or rent without the written consent of the owner or his authorized agent;
    8. Offering real estate for sale or lease without the knowledge and consent of the owner or his authorized agent or on terms other than those authorized by the owner or his authorized agent;
    9. If a responsible broker, failing to supervise the activities of his associate broker or salesperson;
    10. Failing to advise the buyer and seller of all terms of the proposed sale at the time an offer is presented including estimated discounts and closing costs;
    11. Unreasonably failing upon demand to surrender to the rightful owner, any document or instrument in his possession;
    12. Unreasonably failing to produce documents of record in his possession or under his control concerning any real estate transaction under investigation by the commission;
    13. Failing to submit all offers to a seller or buyer;
    14. Commingling the money or other property of others with his own;
    15. Accepting, giving or charging an undisclosed compensation, rebate or direct or indirect profit on expenditures made for others;
    16. Engaging in real estate activity as an associate broker or salesperson involving the representing or attempt to represent a responsible broker other than his responsible broker or a real estate company other than the real estate company under which he is licensed;
    17. Accepting compensation by an associate broker or salesperson from anyone other than his responsible broker;
    18. Acting for more than one (1) party in a transaction without the written acknowledgement of all parties for whom the licensee acts;
    19. Guaranteeing or authorizing any person to guarantee future profits which may result from the resale of real estate;
    20. Failing to obtain written listing agreements identifying the property to be sold or acquired and containing all terms and conditions under which the property is to be sold or acquired including the price or price range, the compensation to be paid, the signatures of all parties concerned and a definite expiration date;
    21. Failing to deliver within a reasonable time a completed copy of any document to all parties;
    22. Conviction of a felony that relates to the practice of real estate activity or to the ability to perform the duties of a licensee or any felony sexual offense or violent crime;
    23. Compensating any unlicensed person for performing real estate activity;
    24. Failing to specify he is being compensated by more than one (1) party and failing to notify all parties involved;
    25. Failing to account for any monies or property received from others;
    26. Failing to keep the funds of others in an escrow or trust account, unless each person with an interest in the funds has agreed otherwise in writing;
    27. Failing to deposit all financial instruments in an escrow or trust account within one (1) banking day in a financial institution in this state, unless each person with an interest in the funds has agreed otherwise in writing;
    28. Failing upon consummation or termination of the transaction to give a full accounting of the monies and property placed in escrow or trust showing dates of deposit, management and withdrawals;
    29. If a responsible broker:
      1. Failing to deliver to the parties in every real estate transaction at the time the transaction is closed a complete, detailed closing statement showing all of the receipts and disbursements handled by the licensees in his office for the parties unless a clear and accurate accounting is furnished by another real estate licensee or a funds holder;
      2. Repealed by Laws 2011, ch. 104, § 2.
      3. Failing to retain true copies of statements required by this paragraph in his files;
      4. Failing to disclose, in every real estate transaction, the names of all real estate companies for which a responsible broker holds a license.
    30. Representing to any lender, guaranteeing agency or any other interested party, either verbally or through the preparation of false documents, an amount in excess of the true and actual sale price of the real estate or terms differing from those actually agreed upon;
    31. Accepting other than cash as earnest money unless:
      1. The fact is communicated to the owner prior to the owner’s acceptance of the offer to purchase; and
      2. The fact is shown in the earnest money receipt.
    32. Refusing to appear or testify under oath at any hearing held by the commission;
    33. Receiving more than three (3) censures from the commission within a two (2) year period.
  2. Upon receipt from the department of family services of a certified copy of an order from a court to withhold, suspend or otherwise restrict a license issued by the commission, the commission shall notify the party named in the court order of the withholding, suspension or restriction of the license in accordance with the terms of the court order. No appeal under the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act shall be allowed for a license withheld, suspended or restricted under this subsection.
  3. All administrative fines collected under this section shall be paid to the state treasurer to be credited to the public school fund of the county in which the violation occurred.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 11; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.11; Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 2; 1997, ch. 128, § 2; 2005, ch. 96, § 1; 2009, ch. 63, § 1; 2011, ch. 104, §§ 1, 2; 2014, ch. 118, § 1; 2017, ch. 166, § 1; 2018, ch. 107, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to the Wyoming real estate commission, see § 33-28-105 .

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, added provisions for administrative fines and probation in (a); and added (c).

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, inserted “this act or” preceding “any rule” in (a)(ii).

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in addition to making stylistic and related changes, in the introductory language of (a), deleted “and impose an administrative fine” after “under this act”; in (a)(xiii), substituted “to a seller or buyer” for “in writing to a seller, if received prior to the written acceptance of any offer”; in (a)(xxvi) and (a)(xxvii), added “unless each person with an interest in the funds has agreed otherwise in writing”; and repealed former (a)(xxix)(B), which read: “Failing to deliver to the buyer a complete statement showing all money received in every real estate transaction from the buyer and how and for what the same was disbursed unless a clear and accurate accounting is furnished by an escrow agent.”

The 2014 amendment, in (a)(v), substituted “buyer or seller” for “owner or lessor”; in (a)(xx), substituted “Failing to obtain written listing agreements identifying the property to be sold or acquired and containing all terms and conditions under which the property is to be sold or acquired including the price or price range, the compensation to be paid, the signatures of all parties concerned and a definite expiration date” for “Failing to obtain written listing agreements identifying the property and containing all terms and conditions under which the property is to be sold including the price, the compensation to be paid, the signatures of all parties concerned and a definite expiration date.”

Laws 2014, ch. 118, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved March 10, 2014.

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, in (a) added “real estate advertising, self promotion as a licensee or” following “any licensee conducting,” in (a)(xvi) added “or a real estate company other than the real estate company under which he is licensed” to the end, in (a)(xxix)(A) substituted “real estate licensee” for “broker,” added (a)(iixi)(D); and substituted gender-neutral terms.

The 2018 amendment, effective July 1, 2018, in (a)(xxii), added “that relates to the practice of real estate activity or to the ability to perform the duties of a licensee or any felony sexual offense or violent crime ” at the end.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

Agent's duty to client. —

The law requires a real estate agent not only to refrain from taking advantage of a client, but also to act with the utmost good faith and disclose any material facts ascertainable by the agent which may affect the client's decision to purchase or sell, as the case may be. Hagar v. Mobley, 638 P.2d 127, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 404 (Wyo. 1981).

Disclosure of terms. —

A broker's statutory duty to advise his client of the terms of the proposed contract is fulfilled when an explanation commensurate with the education and understanding of the client has been made. Snyder v. Lovercheck, 992 P.2d 1079, 1999 Wyo. LEXIS 188 (Wyo. 1999).

Failure to disclose did not constitute fraudulent misrepresentation. —

In an action arising from the cancellation of a purchase contract for a ranch after the purchaser discovered the extent to which two coal surface mining agreements encumbered the ranch, under the general fraud standard contained in paragraph (a)(i), the failure of the real estate brokers involved in the transaction to disclose the existence and the effect of the agreements in a brochure and map was not fraudulent misrepresentation. Sundown, Inc. v. Pearson Real Estate Co., 8 P.3d 324, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 151 (Wyo. 2000).

Liability sounds in tort. —

The liability of real estate agents, brokers and salespersons, as in all actions predicated upon the failure to perform some duty, sounds in tort. Hagar v. Mobley, 638 P.2d 127, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 404 (Wyo. 1981).

Licensee not rendered “incompetent” by furnishing incorrect property description. —

Although furnishing an incorrect property description may be negligent, it does not render a licensee “incompetent” within the meaning of former subsection (a)(ix). McCoy v. Thompson, 677 P.2d 839, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 265 (Wyo. 1984) (decided prior to 1983 amendment).

Lease agreements. —

Paragraph (a)(xx) is a licensing regulatory statute that, by its terms, applies only to listing agreements for the sale of property; it does not apply to lease agreements. Gray v. Stratton Real Estate, 2001 WY 125, 36 P.3d 1127, 2001 Wyo. LEXIS 156 (Wyo. 2001).

Written listing agreement prior to advertising. —

Subsection (a)(xx) does not contain any language which states that the written listing agreement must be obtained before a broker may advertise the property, although the “is to be sold” language indicates that a written listing agreement should be obtained before the property is actually sold. Bowen v. State, 900 P.2d 1140, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 135 (Wyo. 1995).

Effect of agreement to share on suit for commission. —

In an action by a licensed broker for his commission for sale of real estate, fact that broker had agreed to share his commission with an unlicensed person was held of no consequence. Foley v. Hassey, 55 Wyo. 24, 95 P.2d 85, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1939) (decided under prior law).

No violation of subsection (a)(xviii). —

See Erickson v. Magill, 713 P.2d 1182, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 476 (Wyo. 1986).

Applied in

Mader v. James, 546 P.2d 190, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 169 (Wyo. 1976); Wyoming Realty Co. v. Cook, 872 P.2d 551, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 50 (Wyo. 1994).

Quoted in

Toavs v. State, 635 P.2d 1172, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 393 (Wyo. 1981).

Cited in

Wheeler v. Woods, 723 P.2d 1224, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 598 (Wyo. 1986); Willmschen v. Meeker, 750 P.2d 669, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1988); Earlywine v. Peterson ex rel. Wyo. Real Estate Comm'n, 885 P.2d 861, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 148 (Wyo. 1994); Throckmartin v. Century 21 Top Realty, 2010 WY 23, 226 P.3d 793, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Mar. 3, 2010).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Real Estate Brokers and Salespersons — When is a Broker Not a Broker? Walter v. Moore, 700 P.2d 1219, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 485 (Wyo. 1985),” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 241 (1986).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Grounds for revocation or suspension of license of real estate broker or salesman, 56 ALR2d 573.

Suspension or revocation of real estate broker's license on ground of discrimination, 42 ALR3d 1099.

Revocation or suspension of real estate broker's license for violation of statutes or regulations prohibiting use of unlicensed personnel in carrying out duties, 68 ALR3d 530.

Revocation or suspension of real-estate broker's license for conduct not connected with business as broker, 22 ALR4th 136.

Real-estate broker's or agent's misrepresentation to, or failure to inform, vendor regarding value of vendor's real property, 33 ALR4th 944.

Real-estate broker's liability to purchaser for misrepresentation or nondisclosure of physical defects in property sold, 46 ALR4th 546.

Grounds for revocation or suspension of license of real-estate broker or salesperson, 7 ALR5th 474.

§ 33-28-112. Enjoining violations of chapter; penalties for violation of injunction.

  1. Any person who violates or proposes to violate any provisions of this act, or any rules and regulations promulgated under this act, may be restrained or enjoined from the action at any time by an order issued by the district court. An action may be initiated by the attorney general or the district attorney for the county in which the violation has or is about to occur.
  2. Any defendant so enjoined who violates an injunction shall be punished for contempt of court by a fine of not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or by imprisonment in the county jail for not more than six (6) months or both.
  3. Repealed by Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 3.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 12; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.12; Laws 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 22, § 1; 1983, ch. 156, §§ 2, 3; 2011, ch. 104, § 1.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (b), substituted “two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00)” for “one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).”

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

§ 33-28-113. Contested cases; independent hearing officers; appeals.

  1. The commission may contract with independent hearing officers to hear all contested cases arising under this act. The hearing officer shall not be an employee of the office of the attorney general, or an employee or member of the commission.
  2. All hearings shall be conducted pursuant to the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act [§§ 16-3-101 through 16-3-115 ]. A hearing officer has the power specified in W.S. 16-3-112(b). The hearing officer shall make in each contested case and forward to the commission written findings of fact and conclusions of law.
  3. Any judicial review of the administrative decision under the Administrative Procedure Act may be in the district court in the county where the violation allegedly occurred.
  4. Repealed by Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 3.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 13; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.13; Laws 1973, ch. 151, § 1; 1983, ch. 156, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to the Wyoming real estate commission, see § 33-28-105 .

As to judicial review of administrative action, see Rule 12, W.R.A.P.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

Law reviews. —

For article, “A State Central Panel Hearing Officer System for Wyoming,” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 497 (1986).

§ 33-28-114. Conducting business without license prohibited; penalties; civil liability.

  1. Any individual performing real estate activity without first obtaining a license is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine of not more than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or by imprisonment in the county jail for a term not to exceed six (6) months. Upon conviction of a subsequent violation the individual shall be punished by a fine of not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or by imprisonment in the county jail for a term not to exceed one (1) year or both. If a corporation, partnership or association is convicted it shall be punished by a fine of not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
  2. If any person receives any money or the equivalent thereof as a fee, compensation or profit by or in consequence of a violation of any provision of this act, he shall, in addition, be liable to a penalty of not less than the amount of the sum of money so received and not more than three (3) times the sum so received as may be determined by the court, which penalty may be recovered in a court of competent jurisdiction by any person aggrieved.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 14; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.14; Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 2; 2011, ch. 104, § 1.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a), increased the fines, and added “partnership or association”; and in (b), deleted “commission” after “as a fee.”

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

Out-of-state broker may cooperate with in-state broker. —

The purpose of this chapter, protecting the public, is not violated when a broker, licensed in another state, cooperates with a broker licensed in the state, where a sale occurs, in procuring a purchaser, but does not actually conduct negotiations in Wyoming. Bowlerama, Inc. v. Woodside Realty Co., 752 P.2d 1377, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 1988), reh'g denied, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. Apr. 28, 1988).

The award of punitive damages is solely in the discretion of the trial court. Cates v. Daniels, 628 P.2d 862, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 343 (Wyo. 1981).

And cannot be awarded on appeal. —

When the trial court as fact finder does not award punitive damages, an appellate court cannot change such finding or remand it for determination. Cates v. Daniels, 628 P.2d 862, 1981 Wyo. LEXIS 343 (Wyo. 1981).

Applied in

McCoy v. Thompson, 677 P.2d 839, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 265 (Wyo. 1984).

Quoted in

Erickson v. Magill, 713 P.2d 1182, 1986 Wyo. LEXIS 476 (Wyo. 1986); Squaw Mt. Cattle Co. v. Bowen, 804 P.2d 1292, 1991 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1991).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Transactions within public security or guaranty fund designed to compensate those suffering damage or loss on account of real-estate brokers' defalcations, 38 ALR4th 792.

§ 33-28-115. Unlicensed person may not maintain action for fee.

No action or suit shall be instituted, nor recovery be had, in any court of this state by any person for compensation for any real estate activity unless the person was licensed by the commission under this act at the time of engaging in real estate activity.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 15; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.15; Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 2; 2011, ch. 104, § 1; 2017, ch. 166, § 1.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, rewrote the section, changing the description of acts covered by the section.

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, added “by the commission” near the end.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

Unlicensed person cannot sue for commission. —

Where a person was not a licensed real estate broker in the state of Wyoming, the contract between that person and another to sell a business, the assets of which included leases from an airport board, was void and any actions taken by the unlicensed person to sell the business were unlawful and the unlicensed person was prevented from bringing action for his commission under the laws of Wyoming. Doran v. Imeson Aviation, Inc., 419 F. Supp. 586, 1976 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13489 (D. Wyo. 1976).

Single transaction by unlicensed person is violation barring compensation. —

See same catchline in notes to § 33-28-101 .

Suit by licensee sharing with unlicensed person held not affected. —

In action by licensed broker for his commission for sale of real estate, fact that broker had agreed to share his commission with an unlicensed person was held of no consequence. Foley v. Hassey, 55 Wyo. 24, 95 P.2d 85, 1939 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1939) (decided under prior law).

Quoted in

Richardson v. Schaub, 796 P.2d 1304, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 89 (Wyo. 1990).

§ 33-28-116. Real estate institutes and seminars; assistance in sponsoring studies and programs.

  1. The commission may conduct or assist in conducting real estate institutes and seminars and incur and pay the necessary expenses in connection therewith. The institutes or seminars shall be open to all licensees and the public.
  2. The commission is authorized to assist libraries and educational institutions in sponsoring studies and programs for the purpose of raising the standards of the real estate business and the competency of licensees.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 16; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.16; Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to the Wyoming real estate commission, see § 33-28-105 .

§ 33-28-117. Directory of licensees.

The commission shall maintain and make publicly available a directory of licensees, including licenses suspended and revoked which shall contain other data as the commission may determine to be in the interest of real estate licensees and the public.

History. Laws 1971, ch. 251, § 17; W.S. 1957, § 33-355.17; Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 2; 2011, ch. 104, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to the Wyoming real estate commission, see § 33-28-105 .

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, substituted “maintain and make publicly available” for “annually publish,” deleted “a list of” after “including,” and deleted the former last sentence, which read: “The lists shall be distributed to all licensed brokers without charge.”

Severability. —

Section 18, ch. 251, Laws 1971, reads: “If any provision of this act is held invalid, that provision shall be deemed to be excised from this act and the invalidity thereof shall not affect any other provisions of this act. If the application of any provisions of this act to any person or circumstance is held invalid it shall not affect the application of such provision to such persons or circumstances other than those to which it is held invalid.”

§ 33-28-118. License renewals; continuing education; payment of fees; effect of failure to renew; inactive status.

  1. Licenses issued under this act may be renewed for successive three (3) year periods. The commission may establish a grace period for license renewal not to exceed sixty (60) days. The commission may establish a late fee for license renewal not to exceed seventy-five dollars ($75.00).
  2. The commission may adopt rules and regulations providing for mandatory continuing education allocable over each three (3) year period not to exceed sixty (60) hours.
  3. Failure to timely submit a complete renewal application including proof of required continuing education and renewal fees when due shall automatically cause a license to expire. Presentation of a check to the commission as a fee for either an original or renewal license or for examination for license, which is returned to the state treasurer unpaid, is cause for revocation or denial of license unless it is established that the dishonor of the check was not the fault of the applicant or licensee.
  4. Any licensee whose license has expired as provided in this section after the grace period has ended, shall comply with all requirements of a new applicant, including writing the appropriate examination, before a license will be reissued.
  5. Any real estate associate broker or salesperson who is not employed by or associated with a responsible broker, or any responsible broker who desires to become inactive, may renew his license in an inactive status prior to the renewal deadline established in this section, by submitting the renewal fee together with a completed renewal application on which he has noted his present inactive status.
  6. A license on inactive status for more than three (3) years shall not be reissued on an active status unless the licensee has first met the educational requirements under subsection (b) of this section.
  7. A license on an inactive status for less than three (3) years may be renewed on an active status prior to the renewal deadline by submitting the renewal fee together with a renewal application.

History. Laws 1983, ch. 156, § 1; 2005, ch. 96, § 1; 2011, ch. 104, § 1; 2017, ch. 166, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to the Wyoming real estate commission, see § 33-28-105 .

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, in (a), added the final two sentences

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a), deleted the former second and third sentences, providing for timing of application for renewal of licenses; in (b), deleted “Effective December 31, 2983” at the beginning; in (c), substituted the first sentence for the former first sentence, which read: “Failure to remit renewal fees when due shall automatically cancel a license, but otherwise the license shall remain in full force and effect continuously from the date of issuance, unless suspended or revoked by the commission for just cause”; and in (d), in addition to making stylistic changes, added “after the grace period has ended.”

The 2017 amendment , effective July 1, 2017, in (e), substituted gender-neutral terms.

Meaning of “this act.” —

For the definition of “this act,” referred to in this section, see § 33-28-102(b)(lxii).

§ 33-28-119. Advertising; licensing under one name; trade names; advertisement of licensees.

  1. Every real estate licensee, when promoting himself as a licensee, advertising or promoting his real estate activities, shall use the real estate company name under which he is licensed by the commission and shall use no slogans or phraseology in a manner which would indicate or suggest to the public that real estate may be listed or is being offered for sale, exchange, lease or rent by a private party not licensed by the commission.
  2. Repealed by Laws 2011, ch. 104, § 2.
  3. No person shall act or advertise as a licensee in this state by use of letterheads, billboards, radio or television announcements or any other media of advertising, without first obtaining a license from the commission.
  4. No person shall conduct or promote a real estate company other than the real estate company under which the person or company is licensed by the commission.
  5. A trade name, with the permission of the owner of the trade name, may be used concurrently with the licensed name of the real estate company in the promotion or conduct of the responsible broker’s business. On promotional materials the real estate company name shall be displayed in a conspicuous manner that the general public may easily identify, as prescribed in commission rules.
  6. A licensed responsible broker shall not advertise the sale, purchase, exchange or lease of real estate, unless owned by him, without including in the advertisement the real estate company name under which he is licensed by the commission.
  7. A licensed associate broker or salesperson shall not advertise the sale, purchase, exchange or lease of real estate, unless owned by him, without including in the advertisement the real estate company name under which he is licensed by the commission.
  8. A licensee shall not advertise the sale, purchase, exchange or lease of real estate owned by the licensee unless the advertisement includes the fact that an owner of the real estate is a licensee.
